column1: WASHINGTON — The nation in its 16th day without a speaker of the House
column2: and Republican lawmakers have made seemingly no progress towards electing a new
column3: permanent leader.

column1: Instead

column3: R-Ohio
column4: appeared to support a plan empowering Rep. Patrick McHenry
column5: R-N.C.
column6: as speaker up until January to get the House moving again. McHenry has already been serving as an interim speaker with limited powers.

column3: lost a second speaker election. Compared to the first ballot

column2: R-Ark.
column3: one of the holdouts

column1: Follow along for live updates from USA TODAY on the speaker fight.
Meanwhile
column2: just a one-minute walk away from a closed-door meeting where House Republicans are debating a resolution to empower McHenry
column3: House Democrats are huddling to discuss next steps.

column1: The move to empower McHenry as a temporary speaker will almost certainly require a heavy lift from Democrats. Hard-right lawmakers have been leaving the GOP meeting furious and lambasting the resolution.– Ken Tran
A roll call vote to determine attendance in the House
column2: scheduled for noon
column3: has been postponed as lawmakers continue to debate a resolution that would empower McHenry as an interim speaker.

Perry said.

House Republicans are currently meeting behind closed doors to discuss a resolution from Rep. Dave Joyce, R-Ohio, to temporarily empower McHenry as acting speaker.− Ken Tran
Sen. Patty Murray, a Democrat representing Washington state, currently serves as president pro tempore of the Senate.
Without an official speaker of the House, Murray was next in line for the presidency after Vice President Kamala Harris in the case of an emergency.
– Marina Pitofsky
House Republicans will huddle in a closed-door conference meeting at 11 a.m. Thursday to discuss next steps.
The meeting comes as Jordan faces growing opposition to his bid for speaker and talks increase about giving temporary speaker Patrick McHenry more power.
− Ken Tran
As Jim Jordan still faces stiff opposition from GOP holdouts after failing two consecutive ballots, it is unclear when the House will hold a third speaker election.The House will come into session at noon for a roll call vote to determine attendance, but it's uncertain when a speaker vote will be held.
Jordan, R-Ohio, told reporters Wednesday he intends to stay in the race and expected a vote at noon Thursday. But as it remains clear Jordan has no path towards the 217 votes he needs to become speaker, the timing of the third speaker election is up in the air.
− Ken Tran
Lawmakers were originally expected to begin proceedings at noon Thursday in Washington, but timing could change if Republicans meet in conference first. When the House reconvenes, you can follow along here.
– Marina Pitofsky
Rep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., one of the moderate GOP lawmakers opposing Jordan, told USA TODAY the House is in its state of paralysis by the fault of the conservative hardliners who have overturned precedent."

column1: Hard-right lawmakers
column2: Lawler told USA TODAY
column3: "set a new precedent within this congress." The New York Republican referenced multiple times ultraconservatives tanked rule votes
column4: traditionally procedural votes that until this year
column5: never failed.

column1: The historic move to remove McCarthy from the speakership
column2: Lawler added
column3: was done with "no real planning
column4:
resulting in the gridlock that has consumed House Republicans.
− Ken Tran
Rep. Patrick McHenry, R-N.C., was chosen to be acting House speaker from a succession list that McCarthy provided to a House clerk in January in case his seat became vacant.
McHenry is serving his 10th term in Congress and represents the 10th congressional district in North Carolina. He is a McCarthy ally and chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, a role that helped him negotiate the debt limit deal earlier this year.
He was appointed in 2015 by then House Majority Whip Steve Scalise, R-La., to serve as the Chief Deputy Whip, helping Scalise build agreement around a conservative policy agenda for the House Republican Conference. 
−Sudiksha Kochi
Rep. Mike Kelly, R-Pa., one of the GOP holdouts against Jordan voted for former speaker John Boehner on Wednesday in the second speaker election as a protest vote.
The vote drew some applause from House Democrats.
Boehner served as House speaker from 2011 to 2015 and was virtually removed by House Republicans, led by Jordan and the House Freedom Caucus, who threatened to oust him from the speakership akin to McCarthy’s ejection earlier this month. Boehner ultimately resigned in the face of those threats.
– Ken Tran
No. 
Technically, Rep. Hakeem Jeffries could be elected, as there are no requirements for the speaker to be from the majority party (or even a member of Congress). In both rounds of voting this week, Jeffries has received 212 votes, the full backing of House Democrats and more than Rep. Jim Jordan both times.
However, the New York Democrat would still need five more votes to hit the necessary 217.
Despite infighting among Republicans, it's very doubtful any lawmaker on the right, let alone five, will cast a vote across the aisle.
−Savannah Kuchar
The number of votes needed is determined by a majority of House lawmakers present and voting.
On Tuesday, that number was 217. Because no lawmaker received 217 votes in the first election, the speaker race continues today.
When the vote for speaker begins Wednesday, members will have a roll call vote to determine how many are present and voting − and how many votes are needed to win. Then they will be called on individually to cast their vote for a speaker.
Voting could last several rounds Wednesday or be postponed until another day if a speaker isn't elected during the second try.
– Candy Woodall
Rep. Jack Bergman, R-Mich., is prepared to step up" and serve as House speaker to help lead the party out of the chaos both it and the nation currently face
column5: his spokesman James Hogge said in an email to the Detriot Free Press
column6: part of the USA TODAY Network.

column1: It’s becoming clear Rep. Jordan’s path is narrowing by the hour,” Hogge said. ““We cannot go another day without a Speaker. He simply doesn’t have the votes — we need to have a frank discussion as a conference about a path forward. If as a conference we see he can’t get the necessary votes to become Speaker, General Bergman is prepared to step up.
20 House Republicans voted against Jordan in the first House speaker election while 22 Republicans voted against him in the second election. Bergman supported Jordan in both rounds.
Bergman said on X
column2: formerly known as Twitter
column3: on Monday that “We need a leader to step up to unite the Republican conference
column4: actually pass critical legislation
column5: and move our Nation forward.”

When Angel Amankwaah traveled from Denver to North Carolina Central University for incoming student orientation this summer
column2: she decided she had made the right choice.

column1: She had fun learning the chants that fans perform at football games. But she also saw that “there are students who look like me
column2: and professors who look like me” at the historically Black university
column3: said Amankwaah
column5: who is Black. “I knew that I was in a safe space.”

column1: This has in the past two years become an important consideration for college-bound students from all backgrounds and beliefs. With so much attention focused on these issues
column2: USA TODAY and The Hechinger Report present the first-of-its-kind College Welcome Guide showing state laws and institutional policies that affect college and university students
column3: from bans on diversity
column4: equity and inclusion initiatives and “critical race theory” to rules about guns on campus and whether student IDs are accepted as proof of residency for voting purposes.

column1: The digital tables also list
column2: for every four-year institution in the country
column3: such things as racial and gender diversity among students and faculty
column4: the number of student veterans enrolled
column5: the incidence of on-campus race-motivated hate crimes
column6: free-speech rankings and if the university or college serves many students from rural places.

column1: Test our new College Welcome Guide:These tools offer a new lens on campus life.
Students have long picked schools based on their academic reputations and social life. But with campuses in the crosshairs of the culture wars
column2: many students are now also taking stock of attacks on diversity
column3: course content and speech and speakers from both ends of the political spectrum. They’re monitoring hate crimes
column4: anti-LGBTQ+ legislation
column5: state abortion laws and whether students like them ‒ Black
column6: rural
column7: military veterans
column8: LGBTQ+ or from other backgrounds ‒ are represented and supported on campus.

column1: “There’s no question that what’s happening at the state level is directly affecting these students
column2: ” said Alyse Levine
column3: founder and CEO of Premium Prep
column4: a private college admissions consulting firm in Chapel Hill
column5: North Carolina. When they look at colleges in various states now
column6: she said
column7: “There are students who are asking
column8: ‘Am I really wanted here?’”

column1: For some students on both sides of the political divide
column2: the answer is no. In the chaotic new world of American colleges and universities
column3: many say they feel unwelcome at certain schools
column4: while others are prepared to shut down speakers and report faculty with whose opinions they disagree.

column1: It’s too early to know how much this trend will affect where and whether prospective students end up going to college since publicly available enrollment data lags real time. But there are early clues that it’s having a significant impact.
One in 4 prospective students has already ruled out a college or university for consideration because of the political climate in its state
column2: according to a survey by the higher education consulting firm Art & Science Group.

column1: Among students who describe themselves as liberal
column2: the most common reason to rule out colleges and universities in a particular state
column3: that survey found
column4: is because it’s “too Republican” or has what they consider lax gun regulations
column5: anti-LGBTQ+ legislation
column6: restrictive abortion laws and a lack of concern about racism. Students who describe themselves as conservative are rejecting states they believe to be “too Democrat” and that have liberal abortion and gay rights laws.

column1: Sixty percent of prospective students of all backgrounds say new state restrictions on abortion would at least somewhat influence where they choose to go to college
column2: a separate poll by Gallup and the Lumina Foundation found. Of these
column3: 8 in 10 say they would prefer to go to a state with greater access to reproductive health services. (Lumina is among the funders of The Hechinger Report
column4: which produced this story.)

column1: “We have many young women who will not look at certain states
column2: ” said Levine. One of her own clients backed out of going to a university in St. Louis after Missouri banned almost all abortions following the Supreme Court’s Dobbs decision
column3: she said.

column1: Institutions in Alabama
column2: Florida
column3: Louisiana and Texas are the most likely to be knocked off the lists of liberal students
column4: according to the Art & Science Group survey. They’re generally most likely to steer clear of the South and Midwest
column5: while conservative students avoid California and New York.

column1: One in 8 high school students in Florida say they won’t go to a public university in their own state because of its education policies
column2: a separate poll
column3: by the college ranking and information website Intelligent.com
column4: found.

column1: With 494 anti-LGBTQ+ laws proposed or adopted this year
column2: according to the American Civil Liberties Union
column3: prospective students who are LGBTQ+ and have experienced significant harassment because of it are nearly twice as likely to say they don't plan to go to college at all compared with students who experienced lower levels of harassment
column4: according to a survey by GLSEN
column5: formerly the Gay
column6: Lesbian and Straight Education Network.

column1: “You are attacking kids who are already vulnerable
column2: ” said Javier Gomez
column3: an LGBTQ+ student in his first year at Miami Dade College. “And it’s not just queer students. So many young people are fed up.”

column1: It’s not yet evident whether the new laws are affecting where LGBTQ+ young people are choosing to go to college
column2: said Casey Pick
column3: director of law and policy at The Trevor Project
column4: which supports LGBTQ+ young people in crisis. But LGBTQ+ adults are moving away from states passing anti-LGBTQ+ laws
column5: she said. And “if adult employees are taking this into account when they decide where they want to live
column6: you can bet that college students are making the same decisions.”

column1: Since DeSantis takeover
column2: surge in dropouts at New College of Florida

column1: Meanwhile
column2: in an era of pushback against diversity
column3: equity and inclusion policies in many states
column4: and against affirmative action in college admissions nationwide
column5: Amankwaah is one of a growing number of Black students choosing what they see as the relative security of an HBCU. Enrollment at HBCUs increased by around 3% in 2021
column6: the last year for which the figure is available
column7: while the number of students at other universities and colleges fell.

column1: “The real attack here is on the feeling of belonging
column2: ” said Jeremy Young
column3: who directs the Freedom to Learn program at PEN America
column4: which tracks laws that restrict college and university diversity efforts and teaching about race. “What it really does is hoist a flag to say to the most marginalized students
column5: ‘We don’t want you here.’”

column1: More than 40% of university and college administrators say the Supreme Court ruling curbing the use of affirmative action in admissions will affect diversity on their campuses
column2: a Princeton Review poll found as the school year was beginning.

column1: College students of all races and political persuasions report feeling uncomfortable on campuses that have become political battlegrounds. Those on the left are bristling at new laws blocking programs in diversity
column2: equity and inclusion and the teaching of certain perspectives about race; on the right
column3: at conservative speakers being shouted down or canceled
column4: unpopular comments being called out in class and what they see as an embrace of values different from what they learned at home.

column1: More than 1 in 10 students at four-year universities now say they feel as if they downright don’t belong on their campus
column2: and another 2 in 10 neither agree nor strongly agree that they belong
column3: another Lumina and Gallup survey found. It found that those who answer in these ways are more likely to frequently experience stress and more likely to drop out.

column1: Military veterans who use their GI Bill benefits to return to school say one of their most significant barriers is a feeling that they won’t be welcome
column2: a survey by the D’Aniello Institute for Veterans and Military Families at Syracuse University found. Nearly two-thirds say that faculty and administrators don’t understand the challenges they face
column3: and 70% say the same thing about their non-veteran classmates.

column1: Colleges should be “safe and affirming spaces
column2: ” said Pick
column3: of the Trevor Project ‒ not places of isolation and alienation.

column1: Yet a significant number of students say they don’t feel comfortable sharing their views in class
column2: according to another survey
column3: conducted by College Pulse for the right-leaning Sheila and Robert Challey Institute for Global Innovation and Growth at North Dakota State University. Of those
column4: 72% say they worry their opinions would be considered unacceptable by classmates and 45%
column5: by their professors. Conservative students are less likely than their liberal classmates to believe that all points of view are welcome and less willing to share theirs.

column1: “Is that really an intellectually diverse environment?” asked Sean Stevens
column2: director of polling and analytics at the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression
column3: or FIRE
column4: which has launched a campus free-speech ranking based on students’ perceptions of comfort expressing ideas
column5: tolerance for speakers and other measures.

column1: “Anecdotally and from personal experience
column2: there’s certainly a pocket of students who are weighing these factors in terms of where to go to college
column3: ” Stevens said.

column1: Eighty-one percent of liberal students and 53% of conservative ones say they support reporting faculty who make comments that they find offensive
column2: the same survey found. It used sample comments such as
column3: “There is no evidence of anti-Black bias in police shootings
column4: ” “Requiring vaccination for COVID is an assault on individual freedom” and “Biological sex is a scientific fact.”

column1: A professor at Texas A&M University became the subject of an investigation when a student accused her of criticizing the state’s lieutenant governor during a lecture
column2: though she was ultimately exonerated. An anthropology lecturer at the University of Chicago who taught an undergraduate course called “The Problem of Whiteness” said she was deluged with hateful messages when a conservative student posted her photo and email address on social media.

column1: More than half of all freshmen say that colleges have the right to ban extreme speakers
column2: according to an annual survey by an institute at the University of California
column3: Los Angeles; the College Pulse poll says that sentiment is held by twice the proportion of liberal students as conservative ones.

column1: A group of Stanford students in March disrupted an on-campus speech by a federal judge whose judicial record they said was anti-LGBTQ+. When he asked for an administrator to intervene
column2: an associate dean for diversity
column3: equity and inclusion confronted him and asked: “Is it worth the pain that this causes and the division that this causes?” The associate dean was put on leave and later resigned.

column1: “Today it is a sad fact that the greatest threat to free speech comes from within the academy
column2: ” pronounced the right-leaning American Council of Trustees and Alumni
column3: which is pushing colleges to sign on to its Campus Freedom Initiative that encourages teaching students about free expression during freshman orientation and disciplining people who disrupt speakers or events
column4: among other measures.

column1: “I have to imagine that universities that have a bad track record on freedom of expression or academic freedom
column2: that it will affect their reputations
column3: ” said Steven Maguire
column4: the organization’s campus freedom fellow. “I do hear people saying things like
column5: ‘I’m worried about what kind of a college or university I can send my kids to and whether they’ll be free to be themselves and to express themselves.’”

column1: Some colleges are now actively recruiting students on the basis of these kinds of concerns. Colorado College in September created a program to ease the process for students who want to transfer away from institutions in states that have banned diversity
column2: equity and inclusion initiatives; Hampshire College in Massachusetts has offered admission to any student from New College in Florida
column3: subject of what critics have described as a conservative takeover. Thirty-five have so far accepted the invitation.

column1: Though many conservative critics of colleges and universities say faculty are indoctrinating students with liberal opinions
column2: incoming freshmen tend to hold left-leaning views before they ever set foot in a classroom
column3: according to that UCLA survey.

column1: Fewer than 1 in 5 consider themselves conservative. Three-quarters say abortion should be legal and favor stricter gun control laws
column2: 68% say wealthy people should pay more taxes than they do now and 86% that climate change should be a federal priority and that there should be a clear path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants.

column1: Prospective students say they are watching as new laws are passed and controversies erupt on campuses and actively looking into not just the quality of food and available majors at the colleges they might attend
column2: but state politics.

column1: “Once I decided I was going to North Carolina Central
column2: I looked up whether North Carolina was a red state or a blue state
column3: ” Amankwaah said. (North Carolina has a Democrat as governor but Republicans control both chambers of the legislature and hold a veto-proof supermajority in the state Senate.

column1: Florida’s anti-LGBTQ+ laws prompted Javier Gomez to leave his native state and move to New York to go to fashion school. But then he came back
column2: transferring to Miami Dade.

column1: “People ask me
column2: ‘Why the hell are you back in Florida?’” said Gomez. “The reason I came back was that there was this innate calling in me that you have to stick around and fight for the queer and trans kids here. It’s overwhelming at times. It can be very mentally depleting. But I wanted to stay and continue the fight and build community against hatred.”

column1: Thousands of Israelis and Palestinians have been killed and Palestinians have been ordered to evacuate from the northern Gaza Strip ahead of Israel's impending ground invasion
column2: leading to a humanitarian crisis that has brought protests from the United Nations and around the world.

column1: The U.N. said about 1 million Gaza residents have been displaced in just a week
column2: about half of them finding refuge in U.N. schools and other facilities where water supplies are diminishing. The war has claimed more than 4
column3: 000 lives since Hamas launched an unprecedented surprise attack Oct. 7.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the World Health Organization pleaded with Israel on Sunday to immediately reverse evacuation orders for hospitals in northern Gaza
column3: saying the deadlines are impossible to meet and risk additional loss of life. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warned that attacks on health care facilities are already causing deaths and injuries.

column1: The health situation in north Gaza is dire, Tedros wrote on social media. "Evacuation orders by Israel to hospitals are practically impossible to implement and are a death sentence for the sick and injured."
Here are several organizations that are providing aid to people caught in the conflict.
How to cope:The videos out of Israel
column2: Gaza are graphic
column3: but some can't look away

column1: The Alliance for Middle East Peace (ALLMEP) is a coalition of more than 170 nongovernmental organizations that includes tens of thousands of Palestinians and Israelis who share the goal of building peace between the two communities.

Our members are speaking loudly and clearly about the values that unite our community: Opposition to this horrific violence, and a commitment to Israeli/Palestinian partnership on the path to ending it, and achieving peace and equality, the agency said in a statement.

The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) is a humanitarian organization that aims to protect and aid victims of conflicts. The ICRC has been in Israel and the occupied territories since 1967. The organization is asking for donations to improve access to essential services like water and to support livelihood projects.
Doctors Without Borders is a nongovernmental organization that describes itself as an "independent
column2: impartial and neutral" charity that provides humanitarian aid to people affected by conflict
column3: disease outbreaks and natural and human-made disasters.

column1: The agency is seeking donations to continue to provide medical care in the area. The agency has reported overcrowding in hospitals
column2: a lack of medical supplies
column3: and dangerous working conditions as it tries to support the thousands injured by the fighting.

column1: UNRWA has designated shelters to host the estimated 127
column2: 000 people displaced in Gaza. The agency is seeking donations to support its work.

column1: The Jewish Agency for Israel North American Council
column2: an American charity organization
column3: is accepting donations to help victims of terrorism.

column1: Save the Children issued an emergency alert in response to the conflict
column2: noting that escalating violence has left 1.2 million children in need of humanitarian aid. The agency is accepting donations.

column1: National and international organizations that aid victims in the conflict include the Palestine Children's Relief Fund (PCRF)
column2: which works to provide lifesaving medical relief and humanitarian aid.

column1: Founded by former President Jimmy Carter and his wife
column2: Rosalynn Carter
column3: in partnership with Emory University
column4: The Carter Center is a humanitarian aid organization that has been promoting peace and a viable two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict for decades.

column1: After Israel declared war
column2: The Carter Center released a statement condemning the targeting of Israeli and Palestinian civilians and called for international action to end the violence.

column1: A second co-defendant with Donald Trump in the Georgia election conspiracy case
column2: Sidney Powell
column3: pleaded guilty Thursday to a half-dozen misdemeanors dealing with a conspiracy to interfere in the 2020 election.

column1: Legal experts said Powell's central role in the conspiracy
column2: as an election lawyer who baselessly claimed widespread election fraud in 2020
column3: could have an impact on other defendants charged in the alleged racketeering conspiracy that sought to keep Trump in power.

column1: “Miss Powell is at the vortex
column2: the center
column3: the hub of the alleged conspiracy
column4: ” said Gene Rossi
column5: who handled Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations cases in his three decades as a former federal prosecutor and Justice Department official. “She will be a phenomenal witness for the government because she was at strategic meetings
column6: part of important conversations and she was a leader in implementing the scheme to discredit the lawful election of Joe Biden.”

column1: Powell was initially charged with racketeering and six other counts as part of a wide-ranging scheme to overturn the election so Trump could remain in power. She was charged with tampering with election equipment in Coffee County
column2: Georgia.

column1: She pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit theft by taking and five counts of conspiracy to commit intentional interference with performance of election duties. Powell agreed to testify in future trials in exchange for serving six years of probation
column3: 000 fine and paying restitution of $2

column1: Powell is one of 19 co-defendants charged in the case
column2: which alleged a broad racketeering conspiracy. Other portions of the conspiracy included the recruitment of fake presidential electors to vote for Trump despite President Joe Biden winning Georgia
column3: lying about election results to state officials and in court records
column4: and soliciting public officials to violate their oaths of office.

column1: Legal experts said Powell's agreement to testify against others in the case is "very significant" because she dealt at length with Trump
column2: lawyer Rudy Giuliani and others charged in the conspiracy.

column1: I think it's very significant because she is one of the people who was closest to Trump in many of these alleged nefarious activities, and as part of the agreement, she must testify truthfully against Trump as well as the other defendants,' said John Banzhaf, a George Washington University law professor who has been following the case closely. So it is a major victory for Fani Willis and certainly a major concern for Trump."

Powell worked closely with major figures in the chase. She participated in a news conference with Giuliani and co-defendant Jenna Ellis at the Republican National Committee portraying baseless allegations of election in November 2020. Powell met with Trump at the White House
column2: including on Dec. 18
column4: to discuss having the military seize voting machines
column5: which Trump didn't order.

column1: Given the central role she played in public promotion of false claims of election fraud, it seems likely that she has significant information about the role of her co-defendants, said Alexander Reinert
column2: a Benjamin Cardozo School of Law professor.

column1: Kevin O’Brien
column2: a former federal prosecutor now at Ford O’Brien Landy
column3: called it a “very
column4: very smart move” for Powell to pay a fine
column5: avoid jail and keep her law license.

column1: “Rudy Giuliani
column2: as if he doesn't have enough to worry about
column3: should be very worried
column4: ” O’Brien said. “Remember those press conferences the two  gave on all their ‘evidence’ of election interference?”

column1: Rossie said Powell's guilty plea may persuade others to cooperate with prosecutors
column2: turning "the slippery slope into a luge when it comes to cooperators."

column1: Powell is the second co-defendant to plead guilty in the case
column2: after bail bondsman Scott Hall.

column1: The other 17 co-defendants have all pleaded not guilty. Powell’s guilty plea came days before her trial was scheduled to begin Monday. Another co-defendant
column2: lawyer Kenneth Chesebro
column3: who is charged with developing the scheme to recruit fake electors
column4: still has a trial scheduled Monday.

column1: While Powell was involved in a separate part of the conspiracy from Chesebro
column2: Banzhaf said her guilty plea could affect him because he continues to face charges with a five-year minimum sentence and no opportunity for a federal pardon.

column1: I think it's also likely to convince Chesebro because he's in exactly the same boat, Banzhaf said. "Also
column2: it's going to leave him standing alone in the courtroom. If the two of them were tried together at least they have each other
column3: so to speak
column4: a little bit of mutual support. Now he's going to be on his own and his attorney's going to have to work twice as hard."

column1: Prosecutors initially charged Powell with conspiring with Hall and others to access election equipment without authorization and hired computer forensics firm SullivanStrickler to send a team to Coffee County
column2: to copy software and data from voting machines and computers there.

column1: The indictment said an unnamed person sent an email to a top SullivanStrickler executive and instructed him to send all data copied from Dominion Voting Systems equipment in Coffee County to an unidentified lawyer associated with Powell and the Trump campaign.
No place was safe for more than 2 million Palestinians on Thursday as Israeli bombs slammed across the Gaza Strip
column2: including parts of the Palestinian territory that Israel had declared "safe zones."

column1: At least 12 people were killed and dozens wounded Thursday when a residential building in the southern Gaza city of Khan Younis was struck
column2: medical personnel at Nasser Hospital said. The intensified shelling came one day after Israel agreed to allow limited shipments of humanitarian aid into southern Gaza from Egypt.

column1: Israeli Air Forces continued to strike southern areas despite the directive for people in #Gaza to move south, the UN Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) tweeted. The agency said at least 14 of its own staff had been killed and nine more wounded − adding that the "actual number is likely to be much higher" − in less than two weeks since a stunning
column2: bloody incursion of Hamas militants killed more than 1
column3: 000 Israeli citizens and fueled military reprisals from Israel.

Rep. Patrick McHenry, R-N.C., was chosen to be acting House speaker from a succession list that McCarthy provided to a House clerk in January in case his seat became vacant.
McHenry is serving his 10th term in Congress and represents the 10th congressional district in North Carolina. He is a McCarthy ally and chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, a role that helped him negotiate the debt limit deal earlier this year.
He was appointed in 2015 by then House Majority Whip Steve Scalise, R-La., to serve as the Chief Deputy Whip, helping Scalise build agreement around a conservative policy agenda for the House Republican Conference. 
−Sudiksha Kochi
Rep. Mike Kelly, R-Pa., one of the GOP holdouts against Jordan voted for former speaker John Boehner on Wednesday in the second speaker election as a protest vote.
The vote drew some applause from House Democrats.
Boehner served as House speaker from 2011 to 2015 and was virtually removed by House Republicans, led by Jordan and the House Freedom Caucus, who threatened to oust him from the speakership akin to McCarthy’s ejection earlier this month. Boehner ultimately resigned in the face of those threats.

No. 
Technically, Rep. Hakeem Jeffries could be elected, as there are no requirements for the speaker to be from the majority party (or even a member of Congress). In both rounds of voting this week, Jeffries has received 212 votes, the full backing of House Democrats and more than Rep. Jim Jordan both times.
However, the New York Democrat would still need five more votes to hit the necessary 217.
Despite infighting among Republicans, it's very doubtful any lawmaker on the right, let alone five, will cast a vote across the aisle.

The number of votes needed is determined by a majority of House lawmakers present and voting.
On Tuesday, that number was 217. Because no lawmaker received 217 votes in the first election, the speaker race continues today.
When the vote for speaker begins Wednesday, members will have a roll call vote to determine how many are present and voting − and how many votes are needed to win. Then they will be called on individually to cast their vote for a speaker.
Voting could last several rounds Wednesday or be postponed until another day if a speaker isn't elected during the second try.
– Candy Woodall

column2: winter is coming — But how bad is it going to be? Federal forecasters from NOAA's Climate Prediction Center gave us their answer Thursday morning in an annual winter outlook.

column1: NOAA said the U.S. winter of 2023-24 will likely be dominated by the effects of what could be a powerful El Niño. That means a mild
column2: dry winter is likely on tap for much of the northern tier of the U.S.
column3: while the southeastern U.S. should see a wetter-than-average winter.

column1: The center's forecast covers the months of December
column2: January and February
column3: which is known as meteorological winter.

column1: Warmer-than-average temperatures are favored across the northern tier of the U.S. and much of the far West
column2: NOAA said. The greatest odds for warmer-than-average conditions are in Alaska
column3: the Pacific Northwest and northern New England. No parts of the nation are forecast to to be colder-than-average
column4: according to the forecast.

column1: As for precipitation
column2: wetter-than-average conditions are most likely in northern Alaska
column3: portions of the West from California to the south-central Rockies
column4: the southern Plains
column5: Gulf Coast
column6: Southeast and lower mid-Atlantic
column7: NOAA predicts.

column1: “An enhanced southern jet stream and associated moisture often present during strong El Niño events supports high odds for above-average precipitation for the Gulf Coast
column2: lower Mississippi Valley and Southeast states this winter
column3: ” said Jon Gottschalck of the Climate Prediction Center.

column1: The wet conditions across the South should help ease the drought in the region: "El Niño
column2: with its enhanced precipitation
column3: is expected to provide drought relief to the southern U.S. during the next few months
column4: ” said Brad Pugh
column5: of the Climate Prediction Center.

column1: As for where a dry winter is likely
column2: the greatest odds for drier-than-average conditions are forecast in portions of the northern Rockies and central Great Lakes region
column3: especially for Michigan and northern Ohio and Indiana.

column1: The main factor that federal climate scientists use to forecast winter weather is the strength of El Niño or La Niña
column2: climate patterns that affect weather in the U.S. and around the world. The entire natural climate cycle is officially known as the El Niño – Southern Oscillation (ENSO)
column3: which swings between warmer and cooler seawater in the tropical Pacific Ocean.

column1: (El Niño is unusually warm water in the tropical Pacific Ocean
column2: while La Niña means cooler-than-average water in the Pacific.)

column1: This El Niño
column2: which began in June
column3: is predicted to last through the winter. It could be a "historically strong" one
column4: the Climate Prediction Center said
column5: potentially rivaling those from 2015-16 and 1997-98.

column1: Let it snow?:Winter predictions start as El Niño strengthens. Here's what forecasters say.
The forecast released Thursday only predicts where above or below normal temperatures – and above or below normal precipitation – are most likely.
This winter forecast does not specify how much precipitation will fall as rain
column2: snow or ice
column3: only that more or less is likely overall. Snow forecasts depend upon the strength and track of winter storms
column4: which generally cannot be predicted more than a week in advance
column5: the center has said in the past.

column1: As for the 50 million Americans that live in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic
column2: where big snowstorms typically bring the most angst
column3: the climate center does not give a specific forecast for how much snow will fall.

column1: How cold and snowy will US winter be?:Why October snow in Siberia could hold the answer.

Climate patterns such as the Arctic Oscillation – which can unleash intensely cold temperatures across the central and eastern U.S. – aren't included in this official forecast at this time since they can't be predicted more than one or two weeks in advance.
Other large-scale climate patterns in the atmosphere that can influence winter weather include the Madden-Julian Oscillation
column2: which can affect the number of heavy rain events along the West Coast. It can also contribute to other extreme events in the U.S.
column3: including Arctic air outbreaks during the winter months across the central and eastern portions of the nation
column4: the CPC says.

column1: The forecast does also not factor in Siberian snow cover

column1: Lisa Bowman had everything going for her − until she didn't.
The now 56-year-old was the global chief marketing officer for United Way. United Way
column2: an education
column3: economic mobility and health-focused nonprofit
column4: recruited her.

column1: What should've been a dream job spiraled into a nightmare: she alleged she was sexually harassed at work
column2: and more than 20 former employees of the company said "sexual harassment
column3: discrimination and retaliation is commonplace
column4:
at the company, according to a 2021 HuffPost report. The nonprofit fired Bowman in January 2020, months after she reported the harassment. Multiple claims have been filed with the EEOC; United Way told USA TODAY it doesn't comment on matters of employment. The CEO of United Way resigned as the chaos swirled.
But Bowman didn't just lose her job. She lost much more.
The loss of my job was really that loss of my identity
column5: she says. All of a sudden
column6: I went from being Lisa Bowman
column7: CMO of the world's largest nonprofit where anybody would take my call
column8: people were beating down the door to talk to me
column9: to all of a sudden just being Lisa Bowman
column12: so to speak. And that was a really
column13: really tough thing for me to navigate."

column1: Grief doesn't apply to death alone. It comes in a series of shapes and sizes different than you might expect. And all can coexist. (You can share yours with us at the bottom of this article).
There's room enough in the world for all these losses, and one doesn't take away from the other, says David Kessler
column2: grief expert and founder of Grief.com.

column1: Bowman says her grief affected her as a woman: "When I talk about the grief over the loss of a job
column2: I think for women
column3: as we fight so hard sometimes to get to executive levels
column4: and those C-suite positions
column5: when we get there
column6: that job becomes an integral part of our identity
column7: she says. And so we identify very closely with our role."

column1: She attempted to push through her grief – a "fake it 'til you make it" mentality – the same way she dealt with it at 26 following the death of her mother.

She never got to see certain things happen in my life. She wasn't there for a wedding, for example, or to see the career trajectory that I ended up with, which have largely been influenced by her, Bowman says. "And in some cases
column2: this is kind of the same thing. I'm missing out on all of those things
column3: because of this loss of a job. And that in and of itself – it's grief. Every time something happens
column4: and I have a financial challenge
column5: it brings it all back."

column1: Bowman confided in friends and family in lieu of professional help. While none could relate to her quandary
column2: they listened to her. Heard her cry.

column1: She later poured those thoughts into a book – "Harasshole" – which
column2: while therapeutic
column3: made it that much harder for her to get a job. Bowman previously had a 15-year stint in executive-level marketing roles at UPS but now freelances.

column1: It's made it very, very difficult for me to find employment, she says. "I have candidly applied for over 1000 jobs. I've had people tell me that they would love to hire me and they can't
column2: because they can't take a risk with me. I've had job offers rescinded when people have found out about this."

column1: Another kind of grief: missed opportunities.
Bowman's grief is not more or less than any other type of grief. "There's a context to think about it
column2: as sometimes we approach grief like it's a pie
column3: Kessler says. And it goes wrong if we think
column4: Wait
column5: wait
column6: you're taking some of the pie on your job loss. But I need a lot of it because my spouse died. And that isn't how grief works."

column1: Some might call Bowman's job loss "disenfranchised grief" – a loss not openly acknowledged
column2: socially mourned or publicly supported
column3: according to Loree Johnson
column4: a licensed marriage and family therapist. It's grief felt on an individual level not necessarily seen by others.

column1: Plus
column2: "the emotions can be the same
column3: regarding all kinds of loss
column4: says Amy Morin, psychotherapist and the host of a podcast. Someone who lost their job may feel sad
column5: anxious
column6: and a bit disoriented
column7: which might be the same feelings someone experiences when they lose a friend or relative."

column1: Read next:At 25 she found out she had the breast cancer gene. Now
column2: she's grieving motherhood.

column1: Today
column2: Bowman's grief hasn't dissipated. It's morphed: "Similar to the loss of a person
column3: the grief doesn't go away. It's just that you get used to carrying it. So it doesn't feel quite as heavy."

column1: For those going through a similar crisis
column2: Bowman offers these words of advice: "You have to realize that it's not your role that defines who you are. It's who you are that makes you you. It's your skills
column3: it's your capabilities
column4: it's the value you provide."

column1: Passwords might be one of the biggest tech frustrations. Make them too hard
column2: and they're impossible to remember. Too easy
column3: and your accounts are practically wide open.

column1: You could use a password manager or your browser's built-in option to remember your logins. Here's how to find saved passwords in your browser.
Those solutions aren't perfect
column2: of course. Password managers get hacked
column3: and anyone with the know-how can access your saved browser options. No wonder tech companies are working to welcome us to a future sans passwords.

column1: I write about the latest tech gear
column2: security alerts and digital life hacks in my daily emails. Join 600K+ who get the Current each day. It's free!

column1: Woof! It starts with the FIDO Alliance

That stands for Fast IDentity Online. Big tech companies launched the industry association in 2013 to build a better system than passwords we have to keep track of and type in. Now we're seeing more start to roll it out
column2: and Google's beta testing worked so well that the company just made it the standard way to protect your account.

column1: Before we get to how to use passkeys
column2: let's do a deep dive into how they work.

column1: What is a passkey
column2: and how does it work?

column1: A passkey is a personalized FIDO credential (like your fingerprint or face scan) that lives securely on your device. You use that instead of a username and password to unlock your accounts.
Another bonus: No more sticky notes with passwords on your monitor. Passkeys also eliminate the daily "Which password did I use here?" dilemma. Naturally
column2: it'll be faster and easier to log in.

column1: But is it safe to use? Glad you're asking. The unique structure of passkeys makes them near-impenetrable
column2: unlike passwords – which are notoriously easy to crack. Since they're stored on your local device
column3: passkeys can't be hacked or guessed like passwords.

column1: And there's no concern of a hacker getting their hands on one of your passwords and opening the keys to the castle since each device has its unique passkey. That's a far cry from passwords
column2: and studies show most people rely on only a handful of passwords for all their accounts.

column1: Is paid social media the future? If you want privacy
column2: probably.

column1: Want to try it out?
If you're sick of typing in credentials all day
column2: you can set up passkeys with your Google account.

column1: Note: Passkeys are automatically created for Google devices
column2: but you must set them up for any other gadgets you use to access your account(s). You need to do this individually on each device you want to give access to. Remember
column3: a passkey lives on that device
column4: so it's not just an accountwide setting.

column1: ◾ Go to g.co/passkeys.
◾ Tap Get passkeys and sign in.
◾ Select Use passkeys
column2: then follow the onscreen prompts.

column1: You'll be prompted to log in without your password in certain situations. My advice: Use biometric authentication (your fingerprint or face) anywhere you can. It's much more secure than a PIN.
Fear not
column2: Apple folks

column1: You can use passkeys with your iPhone too. These work through the iCloud Keychain. Make sure you have that turned on and two-factor authentication enabled to use passkeys. Note: To use passkeys
column2: iOS 16
column3: iPadOS 16
column4: macOS 13
column5: or tvOS 16 (or later) is required.

column1: Depending on the website
column2: browser
column3: or app you're using
column4: saving a passkey to your iPhone and iCloud Keychain usually consists of these steps:

column1: ◾ On your iPhone
column2: go to the sign-in screen for a supported website or app and do one of the following: If setting up a new account: Tap the button or link for setting up new accounts
column3: then follow the onscreen instructions.

column1: ◾ When you see the option to save a passkey for the account
column2: tap Continue. Your passkey is saved.

column1: Note: If you don't see a passkey option
column2: the app or website doesn't currently support passkeys.

column1: To sign in to an account on your iPhone with a passkey:
◾ On your iPhone
column2: go to the website or app and tap the account name field on the sign-in screen.

column1: ◾ Tap the suggested account name that appears at the bottom of the screen or near the top of the keyboard. If the account name doesn't appear
column2: or you want to use a different one
column3: enter it.

column1: ◾ Use Face ID or Touch ID to complete sign-in. If you didn't set up Face ID or Touch ID on your iPhone
column2: enter your device passcode (the code you use to unlock your iPhone).

column1: The passkey you saved completes the sign-in automatically.
When using a device not associated with your Apple ID
column2: you can still sign in to an account using the passkey stored on your iPhone. Here's how:

column1: ◾ On the other device
column2: go to the website or app and enter your user name in the account name field on the sign-in screen.

column1: ◾ Select Other options
column2: Passkey from nearby device
column3: or similar
column4: then follow the onscreen instructions to display a QR code on the screen.

column1: ◾ Use your iPhone camera to scan the QR code.
The passkey that's saved to iCloud Keychain completes the sign-in automatically.
Now
column2: onward
column3: with your safe new logins.

column4: citing the Russian Criminal Code.

column1: Kurmasheva lives in Prague with her husband and two children.

A program coordinator for the Committee to Protect Journalists called the charges against Kurmasheva "spurious" and demanded her immediate release. “Journalism is not a crime and Kurmasheva’s detention is yet more proof that Russia is determined to stifle independent reporting
column2:
said Gulnoza Said, the nonprofit's Europe and Central Asia program coordinator.
Alsu is a highly respected colleague

column5: said Jeffrey Gedmin, the acting president of RFE/RL in a statement. She needs to be released so she can return to her family immediately."

The NHC says Tammy is expected to turn west-northwest Thursday and northwest Friday

column1: Most people are familiar with the sweet flavor and soft texture of the banana – but some may wonder about its nutritional value – like its upsides

column3: and if we can actually eat them every day. We connected with Kara Burnstine
column4: MSRD
column5: LDN
column6: CDCES
column7: Registered Nutritionist and Certified Diabetes Educator at Pritikin Longevity Center to find out everything you need to know about bananas.

column1: Although bananas have many benefits
column2: there are three main nutritional benefits that we want to focus on.

column1: Are you getting enough potassium?Here's what to know about the mineral
column2: how to get more

column1: The main drawback of bananas is the sugar content. Even though it is natural
column2: too much sugar can lead to issues
column3: particularly if you’re a diabetic or if you have weight loss goals.

column1: Burnstine explains
column2: “All fruits are not created equal in terms of calories and sugar content. Although the sugar content in fruit is natural and preferred
column3: bananas have a higher cost in terms of calories and sugar content than some other fruits
column4: for example
column5: berries."

column1: She adds
column2: “Those with digestive disorders may have trouble digesting the sugars in the banana and they can cause some GI distress. It's a good idea to eat the banana before it gets all spotted like a leopard. The more spotted
column3: the more ripened the banana becomes and increases the sugar content of the banana.”

column1: Burnstine says the short answer is: yes. However
column2: she urges you to think about some of the caveats

column1: “Keep the portions small
column2: have them with fibrous foods like vegetables
column3: and/or pair them with a healthy protein or plant-based fat to increase satiety and dilute sugar concentration.” She gives some examples of what she does at her practice
column4: “Some great pairings would be Greek yogurt with a banana or a handful of nuts with a banana.”

column1: Additionally
column2: the American Heart Association recommends
column3: “Don’t go bananas. But maybe eat one.” They concurred that bananas have lots of wonderful nutrients
column4: but that some people need to worry about the sugar or potassium content
column5: particularly if you have kidney or heart disease.

column1: A fun outing at a pecan festival in Texas took a scary turn when a gust of wind launched a carnival ride car into the air and left its operator dangling 30 feet above the ground.
The ride operator was helping 12-year-old Juliana Bernal get into one of the cars on The Bullet at the 54th annual Groves Pecan Festival on Sunday afternoon in Groves
column2: Texas
column3: about 90 miles east of Houston near the Louisiana state line
column4: reported KMBT-TV

column1: A strong gust of wind suddenly propelled the car into the air with Juliana inside as the ride operator held onto the door to keep it shut and protect her
column2: the station reported. He managed to do that all while the compartment turned 180 degrees and stalled 30 feet from the ground.

column1: Video footage of the accident shared by KFDM-TV showed the operator hanging from the ride with his legs dangling in the air as people screamed and watched in horror.
Now he's being hailed as a hero.
Video:Day of adventure turns into nightmare for Canadian amusement park riders
Juliana's mother
column2: Caress Muraira
column3: told KMBT-TV that watching the incident unfold was one of the scariest moments of her life.

column1: It started going slow at first and he was trying to stop it, her door wasn't closed, she said. "So I started freaking out. As he went to close the door he just kind of flew up with it. My daughter was up there and talking to him saying
column2: 'Please hang on. Don't fall.'"

column1: Juliana also kept telling Muraira: "Mommy
column2: I'm OK
column3:
she said.
It felt like the longest time of my life
column4:
before employees were able to get the ride's motor going and lower the ride, bringing both the operator and Juliana to safety. Just before that the employees quickly removed a handful of children who were in a ground-level compartment of the ride.
The Bullet was shut down for the rest of the event.
Muraira said that she was immensely grateful to the ride operator for risking his life for her daughter.
'Sucked out of seat':Boy thrown from ride at Virginia state fair hospitalized in latest amusement park accident
Groves City Marshal Norman Reynolds told KMBT-TV that the ride operator was shaken up after the ordeal.
Muraira said that her daughter told her that she saw blood on the operator's fingers from where he was holding onto the ride.
A spokesperson for the festival organizer, the Groves Chamber of Commerce, told USA TODAY on Wednesday that the ride operator was fine and that they are not aware of any injuries.
Organized by the Groves Chamber of Commerce since 1969, the Groves Pecan Festival is a community-wide celebration that coincides with the yearly pecan harvest. Pecans are an integral part of the Groves landscape and have been a focal point for community growth, the chamber of commerce says.
A spate of recent incidents related to amusement rides and attraction has left riders stuck or injured.
On Sept. 29, an 8-year-old boy sustained significant injuries when he was sucked out" of his seat on a ride called The Storm at the State Fair of Virginia.

column3: Ohio after the ride known as the Magnum XL experienced a mechanical issue.

column1: Back in July

column3: Wisconsin
column4: ended up in a terrifying predicament when a malfunction left riders stuck upside down for hours.

column1: Just two days before that
column2: a North Carolina amusement park closed one of its rollercoasters after guests noticed a crack in a support pillars and video showed pieces moving out of place as cars moved along the tracks.

column1: Hamas and Israel have been blaming each other for a deadly blast at a Gaza hospital complex.

President Joe Biden backed up Israel’s statements on Wednesday as he visited Tel Aviv. Biden said he was “outraged and saddened” by the loss of life in Gaza City. But he said U.S. intelligence indicated that Israel was not behind the explosion.
Here's a look at what happened
column2: and what the different parties are saying:

column1: An explosion in a courtyard and parking lot adjacent to al-Ahli Hospital in a Gaza City suburb reportedly killed or injured hundreds of patients and people in the vicinity.
Mohammed Abu Selmia − general director of Shifa Hospital
column2: where the wounded and dead were transferred after the explosion − said early Wednesday that he believed the death toll was close to 250
column3: with hundreds more wounded
column4: The Associated Press reported.

column1: The American Friends of the Episcopal Diocese of Jerusalem
column2: which operates the medical center
column3: said in a statement Tuesday evening that hundreds of staff
column4: patients
column5: and refugees who were sheltering at Ahli Arab Hospital were killed and wounded.

column1: Palestinians have been seeking refuge in and around hospitals from the Israeli bombardment of Gaza prompted by the Oct. 7 Hamas rampage that killed 1
column2: 400 people in Israeli territory. More than 3
column3: 000 people have been killed and more than 12
column4: 500 have been injured in Gaza
column5: according to its health ministry.

column1: Keep up with developments from Gaza:Sign up for our Israel-Hamas War newsletter
The U.S. said Wednesday that its intelligence assessments indicated Israel was not behind the hospital explosion.
“While we continue to collect information
column2: our current assessment
column3: based on analysis of overhead imagery
column4: intercepts and open source information
column5: is that Israel is not responsible for the explosion at the hospital in Gaza yesterday
column6: ” National Security Council spokeswoman Adrienne Watson said in a statement.

column1: Air Force Gen. Pat Ryder
column2: the Pentagon press secretary
column3: said separately that the Defense Department’s intelligence assessment is that Israel was not responsible for the explosion.

column1: The Israeli military denied involvement and released video
column2: audio and other information to support its claim that the explosion resulted from a misfired missile from the Islamic Jihad
column3: a militant group that sometimes cooperates with Hamas and is considered a terrorist organization by the U.S. In a video posted to X
column4: formerly Twitter
column5: the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) compares examples of craters caused by IDF ordnance to the damage near the hospital.

column1: Israel Defense Forces posted a video claiming the rocket originated from Gaza. The footage was posted on X with text that reads: "RAW FOOTAGE: A rocket aimed at Israel misfired and exploded at 18:59 − the same moment a hospital was hit in Gaza."
Hamas has blamed Israel for Tuesday's explosion
column2: and its health ministry says the blast killed at least 500 people. Riyad Mansour
column3: the Palestinian ambassador to the United Nations
column4: pushed back on the Israeli narrative in a video posted by The Wall Street Journal and other media outlets.

column1: In it
column2: Mansour appears to be speaking from the United Nations
column3: surrounded by other Arab diplomats
column4: and he says: “It is a lie. And they
column5: the Israeli spokesperson of the army about a week ago made a statement in which he said evacuate the hospitals
column6: the hospitals are target and in fact they hit one hospital a week ago. So their intentions is evacuate or hospitals will be hit. And they are responsible for that crime and they cannot fabricate stories to deal with it.”

column1: Is there any kind of independent investigative team that can resolve the matter by cutting through the politics and examining the forensic evidence to find out who is responsible? The short answer is yes
column2: but with some caveats.

column1: The essential point is that time is of the essence here for an accurate investigation of the site, said David Scheffer
column2: an international law expert who served as the first U.S. Ambassador-at-Large for War Crimes Issues. "You would need a 'dream team' of forensic scientists skilled enough to look at the evidence on the ground and that which has been put forward by all sides
column3: including Israel
column4: the Biden administration and Hamas."

column1: Scheffer told USA TODAY
column2: given the superheated climate around Israel's intensifying war with Hamas
column3: "how would you create the team quickly that would be acceptable to both sides so that it doesn't ignite political fires given its composition?"

column1: Options might include the International Criminal Court
column2: the U.N.-affiliated Commission of Inquiry
column3: the International Commission of Jurists
column4: and the Commission for International Justice and Accountability
column5: but all have their challenges. Learn more here: Could an independent inquiry help assess blame for Gaza strike? Yes
column6: but it's tricky.
