column1: Survive long enough as an NFL quarterback and there will be weeks like this. Heat like this
column2: with hot-take analysts suggesting the quarterback take a seat on the bench. The Falcons (3-3) lost an eight-point game against Washington after two of their final three drives ended with picks by the second-year quarterback. The other possession was rather ugly
column3: too; the ball was turned over on downs that included a sack and two incompletions.

column1: Talking turnovers
column2: Ridder
column4: insisted there wasn’t a connecting thread. Was it accuracy or the play design? Bad decisions or bad routes?

column1: NFL STATS CENTRAL: The latest NFL scores
column2: schedules
column3: odds
column4: stats and more.

column1: There were a couple things on each, where I could’ve made a better read, we could’ve ran a better route, or miscommunication, he said. "Or all three. So
column2: there’s little parts in that entire game – not only with myself but with the whole offense. It’s got to be all 11 guys working on the same page."

column1: In rolling with a young quarterback
column2: the Falcons knew there would be some turbulence along the way with this learning curve. Ridder is surrounded by a strong cast of supporting weapons including first-round picks Bijan Robinson
column3: Kyle Pitts and Drake London. And the defense has improved
column4: allowing them to stay in games.

column1: Yet as natural as it is for the quarterback to attract scrutiny
column2: the crunch-time meltdown on Sunday – which included glaring clock management issues on top of the picks – wasn’t all on Ridder. Arthur Smith
column3: the Falcons coach and play-caller
column4: has fingerprints on this
column5: too.

column1: The Falcons’ operational process during the final minutes was a mess. On at least three occasions
column2: the play-clock nearly ran out as Ridder prepared to call for the snaps. Atlanta probably uses as many personnel packages as any team in the league
column3: which can help create matchup advantages but also requires frequent substitutions. And the unit uses an extensive amount of pre-snap motion
column4: which can also chew up time.

column1: In any event
column2: this stuck out as the issues piled up on Sunday. During one sequence
column3: the flow was so sloppy that after Ridder spiked the football to kill the clock
column4: the Falcons still had to use a timeout as the 25-second play-clock was about to expire.

column1: Asked about the operational issues
column2: Smith fired back with arithmetic.

column1: Two-thousand plays the last two years, Smith said. "Things happen. They are all different. I wouldn’t call that some catastrophic trend. Now they shouldn’t happen. But they’re all different
column2: why they happened. You identify the problem. But you take three plays out of 2

column1: But still. It’s what happened lately. The mishaps on Sunday came with the game on the line.
We can play this game all day, defended Smith
column2: in his third season at the helm. "What about Houston? What about New York?"

column1: In Week 5
column2: the Falcons used a 10-play
column3: 56-yard drive to beat the Texans 21-19 with a Younghoe Koo field goal as time expired. In Week 2 against the Green Bay Packers
column4: they executed a 12-play
column5: 66-yard drive for Koo’s game-winning field goal with just under a minute on the clock. The New York game referenced was Smith’s first victory as Falcons coach
column6: in Week 3 in 2021
column7: when his team beat the Giants as then-quarterback Matt Ryan directed a seven-play
column8: 56-yard drive that culminated with a Koo field goal as time expired.

column1: We’ve won a lot of games handling those situations, Smith added. "Obviously
column2: we didn’t do it last week. We’ve got to get it fixed. This isn’t a trend
column3: a runaway story. Acknowledge what happened. Fix it…Those things happened. That’s not the only reason we lost the game."

column1: Smith pointed to the turnovers
column2: maintaining that NFL teams this season have won just 6% of the games when committing three turnovers.

column1: Go back to Houston, and those guys executed pretty damn good, Smith said.
Ridder didn’t dispute the mishaps with the operational flow
column2: which typically include the process of getting the play-call from the sideline in addition to the substitutions. Ryan
column3: the previous quarterback
column4: was sometimes frustrated with the process during his one season working with Smith. Now Ridder
column5: while not pointing a finger at his coach
column6: is dealing with similar issues.

column1: He summed it up as a matter of paying better attention to detail
column2: yet he also acknowledged the challenges with communication….especially as the play-clock winds down.

column1: It makes you speed things up faster, Ridder said. "That’s something we don’t want to do. It goes back to communication. Everybody knowing where they’re supposed to be…just the details with those plays."
Two of Ridder’s teammates
column2: Pitts and London
column3: commended their quarterback for keeping a calm demeanor amid the late-game chaos.

column1: He’s even-keeled, Pitts said. "When stuff is getting out of control
column2: that’s not when you want to crumble. He’s good at keeping his composure."

column1: Now Ridder – and the rest of his unit – will have to prove capable of growing from the hard lessons.
Editor's note: Part one of a five-part USA TODAY series revealing why America hasn't solved its long struggle with Type 2 diabetes.
For chef Robin Ray
column2: newly married with young stepchildren
column3: the turning point came when a stabbing chest pain sent her rushing to the emergency room.

column1: For Brian Castrucci
column2: the gravity hit when the ER doc who had treated him for a near-heart attack a few weeks earlier gave him a big bear hug. “I didn’t think you’d make it
column3: ” the doctor said.

column1: The crisis unspooled more slowly for James Haynes but started in 2019 when he stepped on a rusty nail and didn’t notice.
The moments were turning points for all three to get serious about addressing their diabetes.
Type 2 diabetes
column2: in which the body can’t properly regulate blood sugar
column3: has become so common it’s almost considered inconsequential. More than 1 in 10 Americans have the disease (though many don't know) and another nearly 4 in 10 are at risk for it. In total
column4: half of all adults and a quarter of teenagers have diabetes or pre-diabetes.

column1: Its financial costs are astronomical. The country spends more than $300 billion a year to address diabetes
column2: accounting for $1 out of every $4 spent on health care.

column1: And its personal tolls are even worse: heart attacks
column2: amputations
column3: blindness
column4: kidney disease
column5: double the risk of premature death. It also causes what’s known as “diabetes distress
column6: ” the daily burdens and emotional toll of living with and managing a chronic ailment that can lead to regular dips in energy
column7: foggy thinking and depression
column8: and a sense of isolation.

column1: The most frustrating aspect of Type 2 diabetes
column2: experts say
column3: is that it has long been largely preventable and controllable.

column1: “We have made tremendous gains in understanding diabetes
column2: ” said Dr. Donald Berwick
column3: a pediatrician and former administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. “The best diabetes care can make a very big difference. You can’t say we don’t know what to do.”

column1: And yet
column2: diagnosed rates of Type 2 diabetes have soared over the past 25 years
column3: and especially over the past dozen – particularly among working-age adults like Ray
column4: Castrucci and Haynes.

column1: Roughly 40% of people who died early in the coronavirus pandemic had Type 2 diabetes
column2: a rate four times higher than people without the disease. Even when elevated blood sugar levels are below the threshold for type 2 diabetes
column3: the risk for heart disease jumps 30% to 50% compared with people with normal blood sugar levels. (Type 1 diabetes
column4: which accounts for 5% to 10% of diabetes
column5: is caused by the immune system and is unrelated to diet or lifestyle.)

column1: America’s failure to address Type 2 diabetes highlights larger problems with our food and medical systems
column2: Berwick and other experts said.

column1: A soda costs less than a bottle of water
column2: a double cheeseburger and fries less than a carton of blueberries. Patients wait months for medical appointments only to see the back of a white coat for the short time they’re allotted. Treating disease costs society far more than preventing it but typically provides more profit for insurance companies
column3: hospitals and the pharmaceutical industry.

column1: The USA TODAY Health team spoke with scores of health care providers
column2: researchers
column3: community leaders and patients for this five-part series to understand why Type 2 diabetes continues to worsen in America despite known solutions.

column1: The answer isn't simple. It involves systemic problems facing everyone in society
column2: not just those with diabetes: a food system designed to sell products; a medical system in which cutting off a leg is less expensive than saving it; the high cost of healthy living and the fact that breaking habits takes a lot more than just personal willpower.

column1: This first story looks at what it takes for people to cope with or overcome the disease.
Then
column2: we explore one community in a David vs. Goliath battle against a food system that fails to prioritize people's health.

column1: More in series:Diabetes runs deep in rural Mississippi. Locals have taken to growing their own solutions.
We next travel to Colorado
column2: which has the lowest level of diabetes in the nation. Yet even in this state
column3: where hiking trails and gorgeous views abound
column4: economic and other disparities make it easier for some people to avoid diabetes than others.

column1: More in series:A diabetes disparity: Why Colorado's healthy lifestyle brand isn't shared by all
It's tough to manage a chronic illness in the face of high medical costs
column2: scattered care and caregiver frustration and burnout
column3: so we highlight that next.

column1: More in series:The steep cost of Type 2: When diabetes dragged her down
column2: she chose to fight

column1: Finally
column2: we explore solutions
column3: addressing why it will take a combination of education
column4: medication
column5: medical devices and improved food access to solve this national problem.

column1: More in series:Solutions exist to end the Type 2 diabetes dilemma but too few get the help they need
The system is fixable
column2: said Dr. Dariush Mozaffarian
column3: a cardiologist and professor at the Tufts University School of Medicine in Boston.

column1: But it will take "sensible action" from across many sectors
column2: including health care
column3: science
column4: nutrition
column5: business
column6: public health and politics to change the financial and other incentives that drive so many Americans toward sickness instead of health.

column1: If we do it all, we could fix a lot of this in 10 years, said Mozaffarian
column2: who serves on the President’s Council on Sports
column3: Fitness
column4: and Nutrition. "If we do it incrementally or don't do it at all
column5: we're all going to be toast in 50 years from diet-related illnesses and a depleted environment."

column1: There’s no question personal responsibility plays a role in fighting diabetes.
Haynes
column2: Ray and Castrucci radically changed their lifestyles and sought help after their come-to-Jesus experiences. They’ve reduced their dependence on daily medication and hope to have saved themselves the horrors of more amputations
column3: blindness and dialysis. They’ve extended their lives and improved the quality of that time.

column1: But like many medical problems
column2: the challenges of diabetes go well beyond individual responsibility and blame.

column1: “There are structural issues that we have to start paying attention to and addressing
column2: ” said Dr. Shivani Agarwal
column3: an endocrinologist who specializes in research and treating young adults with diabetes at Montefiore Medical Center and Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York. Agarwal recently led a series of studies in the journal The Lancet that looked at diabetes rates around the world.

column1: Poverty
column2: the studies showed
column3: was a major driver of diabetes
column4: along with racism and unequal access to healthy food and high-quality medical care.

column1: Personal stories illustrate how these structural issues play out in the lives of so many Americans.
Ray
column3: director of culinary operations at HOSCO/North Sarah Food Hub in St. Louis
column4: got weight-loss surgery and then put her culinary expertise to good use.

column1: Castrucci
column3: who runs a public health nonprofit outside Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: used his advantages provided by his work
column6: salary and insurance to “buy” himself better health.

column1: “I’m healthy because of privilege – not diet
column2: not exercise
column3: not determination
column4: ” he said.

column1: Haynes
column3: a former truck driver and maintenance technician in Gulfport
column4: Mississippi
column5: has fewer material assets
column6: but his attitude and the advantages he does have explain why he's still around
column7: despite all he has been through.

column1: “It’s going to be all right after a while
column2: as long as I keep this spirit
column3: ” he said.

column1: Ray’s love for food began when she was 8 years old
column2: watching Julia Child on TV. During family gatherings
column3: she would run around taking everyone’s dinner order. Then she’d scurry back to the kitchen with a notepad full of scribbles.

column1: Throughout her life
column2: she made fried chicken
column3: pork chops
column4: baked mac and cheese
column5: collard greens
column6: and even a whole roasted chicken filled with wild rice and two sticks of butter – everything that made her soul sing.

column1: In her world
column2: food was home. Food was family. Food was love.

column1: But that was some pretty tough love.

column2: Ray was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes. Her father
column3: grandmother
column4: aunts and uncles all had diabetes. She knew what it meant.

column1: “For you to tell me I can’t have ice blue raspberry Kool-Aid was like you shut down my world
column2: ” Ray said. “I didn’t want to accept it. So
column3: I ate
column4: because you eat through your emotions.”

column1: She didn't dwell on the diagnosis and continued with life. Her culinary career took her to Italy
column2: where she learned and fell even more in love with food. She returned to St. Louis
column3: got married and became a mom to her husband’s two children ‒ “beautiful bonus babies
column4: ” as she described them. Through the years
column5: she continued to express love through cooking and eating.

column2: a stabbing chest pain sent her to the emergency room. Doctors assured Ray she hadn’t had a heart attack
column3: but they warned that her life was on the line. At 5-foot-2
column4: she weighed 334 pounds and had an A1C
column5: a measure of average blood sugar of 11%
column6: well above the 6.5% cutoff to be considered diabetic. Her diabetes – and her diet – were out of control.

column1: “That scared me. … It was gut-wrenching and terrifying
column2: ” she said. “I’m fighting against something that’s fighting me back and I did not know how to win.”

column1: She and her primary care doctor decided she would pursue weight loss surgery.
But she also decided to use her culinary prowess to transform her diet. She reconfigured favorite foods
column2: substituting healthier ingredients: Collard greens cooked in smoked fats or ham hocks turned into a kale
column3: turnip and rutabaga recipe flavored with natural chicken broth fat
column4: oils and seasonings.

column1: She fostered her feelings into new recipes and brought them to North Sarah Food Hub
column2: which partnered with Barnes-Jewish Hospital to make packaged
column3: pre-made meals for St. Louis residents with diabetes and limited access to fresh food.

column1: “I had to restructure the food that I put in my mouth. I had to think about what I was eating and how I was eating and how it was going to be good for my body
column2: ” she said. “I became excited about food again
column3: and food became a joy.”

column1: It isn’t always easy
column2: of course. Ray admits to an occasional cookie craving. But now she takes the time to think about how her body processes that cookie and whether it’s worthwhile.

column1: She hopes her cooking can help other people make the same transformation she did. Her staff at North Sarah helps her create new recipes for others. She wants to provide nourishment that allows people to avoid illness and medicine.
“Nobody wants to take 55 pills
column2: nobody wants to feel like a patient
column3: but how do you fix that? It’s by our food
column4: ” she said. “That should be what we’re teaching our community and our culture and our children. … It’s not always about the macaroni noodle with a smile
column5: it’s about what’s good for your body.”

column1: Castrucci is a third-generation diabetes patient. The lifetime risk of developing Type 2 diabetes if a parent has it is 40%. If both parents have it
column2: the risk jumps to 70%.

column1: He knew he was at risk
column2: but he pushed his luck
column3: he said
column4: by eating poorly during the pandemic and falling out of his exercise routine. With the luxury of working from home
column5: walking to the kitchen and bathroom was often the extent of his daily activity.

column1: On Feb. 14
column2: 2022 – Valentine’s Day – he went to an urgent care clinic
column3: concerned his breathing trouble meant he had bronchitis. His blood pressure measured 210 over 110
column4: well above normal levels that top out at 120 over 80. A chest X-ray showed fluid filling his lungs
column5: leading to congestive heart failure.

column1: The clinic sent him straight to a local emergency room
column2: where he was diagnosed with a blockage of the left descending artery – a clogged artery made worse by diabetes. If he had waited any longer
column3: he would have had a massive heart attack
column4: his doctor later told him.

column1: After his release from the hospital
column2: he went to the drugstore to fill his new prescriptions. The pharmacist told him she couldn’t fill one because it would cost $1
column3: 000. He’d have to wait until his insurance approved it. “Please fill it
column4: ” he said. She stressed the cost. “Fill it
column5: ” he pleaded
column6: putting the charge on his credit card.

column1: Medication helped him lose 70 pounds in three months. When his local drugstore ran out of the weight-loss drug
column2: he easily drove to another pharmacy and then another to find what he needed.

column1: His 100 hours of high-quality cardiac rehabilitation were fully covered by insurance.
For my midlife crisis, I got healthy, Castrucci said.
He could devote all his energy to getting well because he didn’t have to focus on how to afford his care. “(I) paid almost nothing for the whole episode
column2: ” he said
column3: “and never worried about it because I have really good insurance.”

column1: Even so
column2: Castrucci pays out-of-pocket for a cardiologist and an endocrinologist because the best ones near him don’t accept insurance.

column1: Every time he goes to Walgreens to refill his medications
column2: Castrucci said
column3: he sees someone turned away because they can’t afford their prescriptions. When they finally show up in the emergency room
column4: “because they will
column5: ” they will cost the system far more
column6: he said.

column1: “Health outcomes are dictated by economics. It’s a whole side of privilege that we don’t always talk about.”
On the day Haynes stepped on a rusty nail in 2019
column2: he walked all day as the nail pierced the sole of his sneaker and then his foot. By the time he took off his shoe that night
column3: his foot was infected. He landed in the hospital for two months as doctors and nurses tried
column4: mostly unsuccessfully
column5: to get the infection and Haynes’ blood sugar under control.

column1: By the time he was released
column2: he knew enough about Type 2 diabetes to realize his daily blood sugar levels – typically in the mid-400s – were four times above what he had been told to shoot for.

column1: But nothing he did or ate seemed to make a difference. He had long since traded ribs for salads
column2: beer for water.

column1: His wife
column2: Angela
column3: barely noticed when James started wearing multiple pairs of socks
column4: pouring powder on his feet and buying bigger shoes. His feet tingled a lot
column5: he said
column6: but he was coping with it.

column1: James ended up in the emergency room again
column2: dehydrated and in need of antibiotics. The doctor amputated the baby toe on his right foot
column3: leaving a large open wound.

column1:
We're going to leave this open because we'll probably have to take more,” Angela remembered the doctor saying. “I didn't like that we're not going to try to save anything, we're just going to start cutting.”
James was fading.
His arm muscles shriveled and he lost his Popeye physique. Antibiotics left him looking sickly, his voice so weak Angela could barely hear him. “I felt like I was watching my husband slowly dying,” she said.
Finally, taking her doctor sister’s advice, Angela emailed Dr. Foluso Fakorede’s office to ask for an appointment. She thought it would take months to get James in to see the heart disease specialist, but the office called and asked if they could come the next day. 
The Hayneses would end up going back to see Fakorede many times − sometimes twice in one week, driving more than five hours each way from Gulfport north to Cleveland, Mississippi.
“We started looking forward to these visits because there was always hope,” Angela Haynes said, though she felt guilty they were taking up so much of the important doctor’s time. 
Fakorede, who is on a personal mission to save people with diabetes from amputations, noticed what other doctors had missed. Haynes had blockages in blood vessels on both legs. 
Once he got the blood flowing again, Haynes began to feel better. His flesh returned to its normal color. The wound started healing at last. Walking became easier.
Then disaster struck again. 
On July 2, 2022, Haynes caught COVID-19. Everything went downhill after that
column2:
he said.
During his 13-day illness, the bacteria in his foot raged out of control. He ended up back in the hospital and unable to withstand the long drive to Fakorede’s office.
Every week, a surgeon would come to the door of his hospital room and before even stepping all the way in ask Haynes whether he had decided to get his leg amputated. 
This is my leg. I was born with this. And you're walking in like you're cutting a piece of cake
column3:
Haynes said.
He was worried about how he’d get around, how he’d be able to work to support his family if he had only one leg. No one took the time to explain why they thought the leg needed to come off or how he’d cope without it, Haynes said. 
In late November, he was finally sent home in a wheelchair. But just three weeks later, as he was getting out of the car after wound care, his right leg gave out and he fell to the ground. Back at the hospital, Haynes was told his foot was broken, essentially beyond repair. He agreed to a below-the-knee amputation.
Released right before Christmas, he spent the next three weeks in bed wondering how he’d manage the rest of his life.
Finally, it looked as if his luck might be turning around.
With the leg gone, his diabetes improved. His blood sugar dropped into the 120s or one-teens. His blurry vision cleared up.
During his long hospital stay, he befriended nurses and learned about a program for people who needed prostheses. The man who ran it called early in the year and said he had received a donated leg. If it fit Haynes, he could have it while waiting for insurance to pay for a personalized one. Miraculously, it did. 
Haynes spent the next six months teaching himself to walk again. The donor leg was heavy and uncomfortable. He wasn't mobile enough to hold down a job.
One late spring night, picking up dinner at a nearby restaurant, he headed to the bathroom for a pit stop. A sink had been leaking all day and Haynes slipped in the puddle, falling backward.
He's still recovering from the resulting wrist surgery.
He and Angela are living – barely – off her part-time salary as a secretary and a church organist.
Haynes has tried at least three or four times" to receive government assistance
column4: but they keep losing his paperwork
column5: or not believing he's disabled
column6: though he once checked himself out of the hospital and arrived at an appointment in his wheelchair to prove he didn't have a leg.

column1: Still
column2: he clings to his faith and the positive attitude he has long used to cheer up himself and others. These are his secret weapons against diabetes and everything else life throws his way.

column1: I try to put a smile on other people's faces, he said. "It keeps my day going."

column1: We can't wait to see what you've been reading!
U.S. household wealth ballooned at a record pace during the pandemic as the government doled out unprecedented aid
column2: Americans hunkered down amid widespread lockdowns and stock and home values soared
column3: according to a Federal Reserve survey.

column1: From 2019 to 2022
column2: the median net worth of U.S. families surged 37% to $192
column4: adjusted for inflation – the largest rise in the history of the Fed's Survey of Consumer Finances
column5: which is conducted every three years.

column1: Median income
column2: meanwhile
column3: grew a relatively modest 3%
column4: and debt was fairly stable
column5: the Fed said in the report.

column1: During the pandemic
column2: many households received financial windfalls from the government in an effort to tide families over amid widespread business shutdowns and 22 million layoffs. That included three rounds of stimulus checks
column3: enhanced unemployment benefits and a pause in student loan repayments.

column1: From 2019 to 2022
column2: the share of families owning stocks increased from 15% to 21%
column3: the largest on record. Median stock holdings fell to $15
column4: 000 from $29
column6: but that’s because new stock owners held smaller portfolios than longstanding stockholders.

column1: The share of families owning homes rose to 66.1% from 64.9%
column2: and the median home value increased 24% to $323
column3: 200. During the pandemic
column4: millions of Americans left cities and bought homes in suburbs or rural areas
column5: often purchasing larger houses to accommodate the increased time they spent at home and their remote work set-ups.

column1: The large wealth gains during the pandemic likely have been pared back since last year
column2: a trend that wasn't captured in the survey. Stock prices have declined as the Fed has raised interest rates sharply to fight inflation and home values have fallen in many regions amid soaring mortgage rates.

column1: During the pandemic
column2: however
column3: the gains were substantial and broad-based
column4: lifting all racial
column5: income
column6: age and education and other groups. Families that didn’t finish high school notched the largest median gain in net worth at 60%. The net worth of Black families also rose 60%
column7: the largest among racial groups
column8: but their median wealth totaled $44

column1: The bottom one-fourth of households by wealth experienced the largest jump
column2: with their median net worth rising to $3
column3: 500 from $400. The pace of the increase was progressively smaller for richer households with the top tenth posting a 26% rise to $3.8 million. However
column4: that still amounted to the biggest increase in dollar terms.

column1: Among income groups
column2: the wealth gain was largest (69%) for the top 80% to 90% of income earners and smallest (24%) for those in the bottom one-fifth.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: from 2018 to 2021
column3: median income rose a relatively modest 3% to $70
column4: 300. The gain captured government assistance such as enhanced unemployment and food stamp benefits but not stimulus payments
column5: the Fed said.

column1: A hefty 28% of families said their income was unusual in 2021
column2: “reflecting the large imprint that COVID-19 and myriad pandemic-related policies left on the U.S. economy.” More families
column3: however
column4: reported lower-than-usual than higher-than-usual income
column5: underscoring the pain inflicted by layoffs and a decline in working hours during the depths of the crisis.

column1: Median income gains were concentrated among families with a college degree. For those without a high school diploma

Yet over the last week, Biden has received glowing reviews from conservatives who once criticized Biden's foreign policy with Israel.

column4: the Texans

said Hall of Fame Oilers QB Warren Moon, who also hopes the Titans will get to wear the jerseys in Houston someday in appreciation of those fans.
They finally came to their senses and brought back their slick J-E-T-S logo from the 1980s in the “Legacy White” package they’ve already used to honor the “New York Sack Exchange” twice this season – including opening night. You remember, when new QB Aaron Rodgers got the win in his glorious NYJ debut. Moving forward, boys, let’s continue catching up to the Giants by also adding a home green jersey to pair with the flashback Boeing-esque sigil. After that, let’s maybe consider an entirely radical logo – which actually incorporates the silhouette of a jet fighter – and slap that on your crowns while scrapping the dopey Stealth Black helmet introduced in 2022.
When it comes to the extra uniform – forgettable throwbacks or gray Color Rush – they’ve done alternate in pretty much the most forgettable ways. Until now. Make sure you see Week 8’s Monday night game at Ford Field, when the Lions will break out their new metallic “Honolulu Blue” helmets featuring their 1960s alternate logo plus two stripes – the display effectively a nice co-brand with Ford’s famous Mustang, another icon from the ‘60s. Very cool way to commemorate what’s already becoming a memorable season between the lines for the NFC North leaders, not to mention the franchise’s 90th year as the Lions.
You could argue – and I have – no club has better unis. Not only that, since moving back to LA and updating their closets in 2020, they’ve given themselves so many mix-and-match scenarios, in addition to the royal blue and navy (with corresponding helmet lightning bolt) Color Rush options. But as much as folks used to pine for their Powder Blue alternates – which have lost just a little luster in the current iteration – now it’d be nice if the Bolts could either bring back the royal helmet with sunshine-y lightning used in the Air Coryell days, or the navy buckets with white bolts rocked by Junior Seau, LaDainian Tomlinson and so many others. (For the record, love the navy and white.)
Let’s commend them for maximizing the use – three appearances this season – of the retro red helmets and original logo with the black, white and gold striping mix meant to honor both the University of Georgia and Georgia Tech. Wouldn’t mind occasionally seeing the classic falcon on the black helmets as a callback to the Deion Sanders days, but that can wait. At least we won’t be subject to those vile gradient alternate jerseys in 2023.
Little reason to mess with something that’s practically perfect, but their deviations work well. The “Steel Curtain” era throwbacks won’t pop off the screen, but the 1970s number font style is the giveaway. Pittsburgh’s all-black Dark Knight look is among the best alternates going – especially when you consider the mistake it would be to revive some of the club’s awful appearances from yesteryear, bumblebees, shoulder swatches and whatnot.
Sunday afternoon, they’re going to roll out their new “Indiana Nights” one-off for 2023. Couple of thoughts here. They’ve added black helmets because Indy fans allegedly demanded them, and they play into the nocturnal theme – fine … aside from the fact the Colts have zero prime-time games this year. Otherwise, this is fairly boss. The secondary logo – with the state of Indiana serving as the center of the “C” for Colts on the shoulder is a plus. But the “heather pattern” used for the blue-on-blue uniform – golfers will recognize it immediately – really distinguishes this get-up.
Never too far afield, their alternates provide truly nice subtleties. They reverted to the “Purple People Eaters” days while rocking The Vikings Classic” in Week 1. And keep your eyes peeled for the perfectly pleasing and pristine purple-and-gold alternates.

column1: Indianapolis Colts quarterback Anthony Richardson will indeed undergo shoulder surgery that will end his rookie season after just four games. Team owner Jim Irsay made the announcement Wednesday.

column2: with surgery possible in the next week or so. Richardson suffered a reported Grade 3 AC joint sprain in his shoulder during a Week 5 win over the Tennessee Titans and was placed on injured reserve last week.

column1: The No. 4 overall pick in April's NFL draft missed two games and left two others early as the Colts have gotten off to a 3-3 start.

After consultation with our medical staff, Anthony, and those close to him, it has been determined that he will undergo surgery to repair his injured shoulder, which will end his season, Irsay said in a statement. "Anthony is a competitor
column2: and we know how difficult and disappointing this is for him and our team.

column1: We collected several medical opinions and we felt this was the best course of action for his long-term health. We anticipate a full recovery and there is no doubt Anthony has a promising future.

column1: Boole said this claim previously surfaced several years ago when Roberts was edited into pictures that were shared on social media.
The current version of the claim hinges on an IMDB entry that listed Roberts as playing Biden at his 2021 inauguration. The linked page is now dead
column2: and the credit has been removed from his profile on the site. But an archive of the page shows it was on IMDB on Aug. 19 and taken down no later than Sept. 15.

column1: Users can submit a request to add a TV or movie title or an on-screen credit to IMDB
column2: according to its guidelines. Those are supposed to be reviewed by editors before they can be published.

column1: IMDB did not respond to a request for comment. Boole said she had no idea how that credit was attached to Roberts and had no record of him ever portraying Biden in any project.
Fact check: Baseless claims of John Fetterman body double still circulating online
Baseless claims that Biden has a body double are not new. USA TODAY has debunked claims that Biden died in 2019 and was secretly replaced by either his (non-existent) twin or an actor
column2: as well as a claim that his body double revealed himself by signing documents with the wrong hand.

column1: USA TODAY could not reach the user who shared the post for comment.
Lead Stories debunked an earlier version of the Roberts claim.
Thank you for supporting our journalism. You can subscribe to our print edition
column2: ad-free app or e-newspaper here.

column1: Our fact-check work is supported in part by a grant from Facebook.
A second co-defendant with Donald Trump in the Georgia election conspiracy case
column2: Sidney Powell
column3: pleaded guilty Thursday to a half-dozen misdemeanors dealing with a conspiracy to interfere in the 2020 election.

column1: Legal experts said Powell's central role in the conspiracy
column2: as an election lawyer who baselessly claimed widespread election fraud in 2020
column3: could have an impact on other defendants charged in the alleged racketeering conspiracy that sought to keep Trump in power.

column1: “Miss Powell is at the vortex
column2: the center
column3: the hub of the alleged conspiracy
column4: ” said Gene Rossi
column5: who handled Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations cases in his three decades as a former federal prosecutor and Justice Department official. “She will be a phenomenal witness for the government because she was at strategic meetings
column6: part of important conversations and she was a leader in implementing the scheme to discredit the lawful election of Joe Biden.”

column1: Powell was initially charged with racketeering and six other counts as part of a wide-ranging scheme to overturn the election so Trump could remain in power. She was charged with tampering with election equipment in Coffee County
column2: Georgia.

column1: She pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit theft by taking and five counts of conspiracy to commit intentional interference with performance of election duties. Powell agreed to testify in future trials in exchange for serving six years of probation
column3: 000 fine and paying restitution of $2

column1: Powell is one of 19 co-defendants charged in the case
column2: which alleged a broad racketeering conspiracy. Other portions of the conspiracy included the recruitment of fake presidential electors to vote for Trump despite President Joe Biden winning Georgia
column3: lying about election results to state officials and in court records
column4: and soliciting public officials to violate their oaths of office.

column1: Legal experts said Powell's agreement to testify against others in the case is "very significant" because she dealt at length with Trump
column2: lawyer Rudy Giuliani and others charged in the conspiracy.

column1: I think it's very significant because she is one of the people who was closest to Trump in many of these alleged nefarious activities, and as part of the agreement, she must testify truthfully against Trump as well as the other defendants,' said John Banzhaf, a George Washington University law professor who has been following the case closely. So it is a major victory for Fani Willis and certainly a major concern for Trump."

Powell worked closely with major figures in the chase. She participated in a news conference with Giuliani and co-defendant Jenna Ellis at the Republican National Committee portraying baseless allegations of election in November 2020. Powell met with Trump at the White House
column2: including on Dec. 18
column4: to discuss having the military seize voting machines
column5: which Trump didn't order.

column1: Given the central role she played in public promotion of false claims of election fraud, it seems likely that she has significant information about the role of her co-defendants, said Alexander Reinert
column2: a Benjamin Cardozo School of Law professor.

column1: Kevin O’Brien
column2: a former federal prosecutor now at Ford O’Brien Landy
column3: called it a “very
column4: very smart move” for Powell to pay a fine
column5: avoid jail and keep her law license.

column1: “Rudy Giuliani
column2: as if he doesn't have enough to worry about
column3: should be very worried
column4: ” O’Brien said. “Remember those press conferences the two  gave on all their ‘evidence’ of election interference?”

column1: Rossie said Powell's guilty plea may persuade others to cooperate with prosecutors
column2: turning "the slippery slope into a luge when it comes to cooperators."

column1: Powell is the second co-defendant to plead guilty in the case
column2: after bail bondsman Scott Hall.

column1: The other 17 co-defendants have all pleaded not guilty. Powell’s guilty plea came days before her trial was scheduled to begin Monday. Another co-defendant
column2: lawyer Kenneth Chesebro
column3: who is charged with developing the scheme to recruit fake electors
column4: still has a trial scheduled Monday.

column1: While Powell was involved in a separate part of the conspiracy from Chesebro
column2: Banzhaf said her guilty plea could affect him because he continues to face charges with a five-year minimum sentence and no opportunity for a federal pardon.

column1: I think it's also likely to convince Chesebro because he's in exactly the same boat, Banzhaf said. "Also
column2: it's going to leave him standing alone in the courtroom. If the two of them were tried together at least they have each other
column3: so to speak
column4: a little bit of mutual support. Now he's going to be on his own and his attorney's going to have to work twice as hard."

column1: Prosecutors initially charged Powell with conspiring with Hall and others to access election equipment without authorization and hired computer forensics firm SullivanStrickler to send a team to Coffee County
column2: to copy software and data from voting machines and computers there.

column1: The indictment said an unnamed person sent an email to a top SullivanStrickler executive and instructed him to send all data copied from Dominion Voting Systems equipment in Coffee County to an unidentified lawyer associated with Powell and the Trump campaign.
Iowa state Rep. Brad Sherman took the stage at a Cedar Rapids auditorium as supporters of Donald Trump continued to file in
column2: buzzing as they awaited the arrival of the former president.

column1: Sherman began Saturday afternoon's program with a prayer.
This is not a time for politics as usual, not a time for religion as usual, not a time for prayers as usual, said the Williamsburg Republican
column2: who is also a pastor at Solid Rock Church in Coralville.

column1: He prayed for Israel
column2: which had been attacked by Hamas a day earlier
column3: and said "we're at war in this nation as well" — a "spiritual war
column4:
in which the Republican frontrunner for president is on the front lines.
They've shot their lying arrows at him
column5: Lord
column6: without cause
column7: Sherman said of Trump. His family and all those who seek good have become targets. … Lord
column8: injustice is hanging over this nation like a dark storm."

column1: Prayers and invocations like Sherman's are not unusual on the presidential campaign trail in Iowa
column2: where Republican politicking intertwines itself with the Christian evangelical leanings shared by many potential caucusgoers.

column1: Some devotions are directed at candidates — calling on God to "release your strategic planning upon President Trump
column2: as a prayer in Ottumwa declared, or asking for attendees to hear Vivek (Ramaswamy)'s heart
column3:
as Kimberly Chapman did at an event for the candidate in West Des Moines.
A few take aim at political opponents: A prayer to kick off a Tim Scott event in August asked the attendees to realize that those on the left hate you
column4: hate your word
column5: in many cases hate our country."

column1: The prayers
column2: often accompanied by a pledge of allegiance and the national anthem
column3: provide a glimpse into how religious leaders and attendees channel their frustrations with President Joe Biden
column4: their fervor for a candidate or their policy priorities through their faith — at a time when division and unease increasingly define American politics.

column1: I think there's a high anxiety within people of faith, and it seems to be increased, said Bob Vander Plaats
column2: CEO of conservative Christian advocacy group The Family Leader. "But I would say that it's kind of a broader reflection on the culture as a whole."

column1: Iowa caucuses:Track candidates' visits to Iowa
Sherman
column2: who has endorsed Trump
column3: believes both religion and politics "have drifted far away from what we were originally." Moving toward an electoral process fully imbued in faith
column4: he says
column5: is necessary to fight the "spiritual war" he spoke of on stage in Cedar Rapids.

column1: Few people seem to think about the fact that if demons and demonic spirits exist, then that means angels exist as well, he told the Register in an interview. "They're doing battle in the spirit."
The outcomes of those battles
column2: he says
column3: "often have a big effect on what's happening in the natural" world — including the results of the Iowa caucuses.

column1: War in Ukraine
column2: and now between Israel and Hamas in the Middle East
column3: has lent a new urgency to those invocations. At an event for Ron DeSantis on Oct. 8
column4: the Rev. Jeremy Higgins of Calvary Community Church
column5: who said he had visited Israel 17 times
column6: led a prayer in support of the country's military and civilians.

column1: Your word tells us to pray for the peace of Jerusalem, so Lord, we do that, but also the nation of Israel as a whole, Higgins said. "And we also want to lift up the men and women in Gaza who aren't a part of these terrorist organizations
column2: and there are so many who live there … who love you
column3: Lord God
column4: and have nothing to do with this."

column1: That uncertainty abroad
column2: combined with a critical primary cycle for the future of the Republican Party and a large chunk of religious voters in Iowa
column3: has prompted some to demand even more direct involvement in the caucus process from parishes and faith leaders.

column1: I would be really, really glad, and I think some of the candidates, to really encourage more involvement by the faith community, Linn County Republican chair Bernie Hayes told the Register. "I feel that at least in circles that I run in
column2: it's lackadaisical. They run from the word 'political.'"

column1: In the eyes of many faith leaders
column2: the crowd of presidential hopefuls is more than just politicians vying for support in the first-in-the-nation caucus state — they're "instruments" of faith
column3: given "assignments" and "callings" to lead
column4: and "serve the interests of God."

column1: Chapman
column2: the Iowa lobbyist who serves as an adviser to Ramaswamy's campaign
column3: said she had prayed and attended church alongside the entrepreneur and author. Though Ramaswamy is Hindu
column4: she said
column5: he "welcomes Christian prayer."

column1: Vivek, when you talk about being an instrument, and God using you as an instrument, that reminds me and my Christian faith of God using us as a vessel, is how we would say that, Chapman said as she introduced the candidate in West Des Moines earlier this month.
Other expressions of faith toward the candidates are more direct
column2: even physical: at a Des Moines church in September
column3: Rep. Jon Dunwell
column4: R-Newton
column5: led a prayer in which a group gathered around DeSantis and laid hands on him.

column1: Many are looking for the next torchbearer for what former President Ronald Reagan called a "spiritual revival
column2:
Vander Plaats said, centering faith in the world of conservative politics. (For his part, Vander Plaats has expressed a desire for the GOP to move on from Trump.)
Candidates traveling through Iowa aim to position themselves as the best one to usher in that revival — attending church, shaking hands and courting endorsements from faith leaders, and emphasizing their opposition to abortion.
The former president, who generally speaks little of his own faith, is preceded on stage at rallies by prayer, and leans on his record and previous support among evangelical voters.
But such prayers on the campaign trail shouldn't have a personal agenda
column3: Vander Plaats said, and should be focused on seeing God's will be done" by an elected leader.

column1: Ultimately what you're doing in the act of prayer itself is recognizing that God is God, and you are not, Vander Plaats said
column2: chuckling and adding "that seems to be a problem we have today."

column1: Sherman believes that "God does place assignments
column2: callings" on people
column3: and that includes candidates for elected office. He's not concerned by those who don't believe in blending prayer and politics.

column1: You can take just the flip side of that and say, well, I'm uncomfortable with people that don't believe in it, he said. "Christianity never forces itself on anyone. I mean
column2: you can't legislate a heart change inside of somebody."

column1: I will stand for people's right to believe whatever they want to believe, that's freedom, Sherman added. "But I'm not going to be muzzled from telling what I believe."
Katie Akin and William Morris contributed reporting.
Galen Bacharier covers politics for the Register. Reach him at gbacharier@registermedia.com or (573) 219-7440
column2: and follow him on Twitter @galenbacharier.

column1: During one of the busiest periods in the still early 2024 presidential campaign
column2: White House hopefuls are making a civic pilgrimage to New Hampshire.

column1: The Republican contenders are chatting with people at diners
column2: coffee shops and bookstores. Some are trekking to the state capitol in Concord to sign their name at a historic desk to be on the ballot.

column1: Others are sharing their messages through several town halls and other stops
column2: including a GOP dinner that happens once every eight years.

column1: Voters have a message
column2: too: some of you need to drop out.

column1: It’s still early. There's still a lot on that stage, said Laura Williams
column2: a registered Republican from Rochester
column3: N.H.
column4: who plans to vote in the primary. "Let some weed themselves out
column5: and those that rise to the top
column6: you know
column7: we’ll wait it out and see."

column1: Whether Granite State natives or political tourists traveling across states lines to get a closer glimpse at the candidates
column2: many are wishing for fewer options after what some called a disastrous second primary debate hosted by the Republican National Committee in California.

column1: Frankly, I was put off by all their debate performances in the last one. They were all talking over one another, Vaughn Annis
column2: a retired chemical engineer
column3: told USA TODAY.

column1: The field was too crowded on that stage to get anything as a meaningful debate.
Annis
column2: a registered Republican who hails from Henniker
column3: N.H.
column4: hasn't made up his mind on a presidential candidate
column5: but he is giving Nikki Haley
column6: Ron DeSantis and Tim Scott closer attention.

column1: A candidate he would like to see exit this race is former Donald Trump
column2: the frontrunner with a commanding lead.

column1: Where I have voted in the past for him, I think Trump needs to step aside and let others move forward, younger people in the party that aren't as controversial, Annis said. "I think that would be helpful for not only the party but also the country."
A USA TODAY/Boston Globe/Suffolk University survey of likely voters showed Trump at 49% with Haley
column2: a former South Carolina governor
column3: the closest rival at 19%.

column1: The non-Trump voters say they are hoping one of the other Republicans can break through
column2: but they are by no means certain that's possible.

column1: Larry Provencher
column2: a semi-retired artist in Exeter
column3: N.H.
column4: fears Trump may be the Republican nominee
column5: adding how he believes the former president "just lost a few upstairs."

column1: He said when interacting with voters
column2: the other candidates need to share their vision in detail and forget about the frontrunner.

column1: You know, like, Chris Christie, I think his main goal is to get Trump out. I want to hear what else you're gonna do, Provencher said.
Those in the anti-Trump camp said they are hoping if some of the other candidates exit
column2: they will unite behind a single challenger. In the most recent example
column3: former Rep. Will Hurd
column4: of Texas
column5: left the race and endorsed Haley.

column1: Haley
column2: a former UN ambassador
column3: has surged in the New Hampshire poll ahead DeSantis
column4: the governor of Florida who was once held as chief alternative to Trump.

column1: Norman Stuart
column2: a veteran and retired machine shop worker
column3: attended a Haley event at the Rochester American Legion last week. He was impressed with her
column4: but he remains undecided.

column1: Although Stuart said he was considering several of the candidates
column2: who he declined to name
column3: he stated emphatically: "I did not go to Wolfeboro to see Trump."

column1: That provides a glimmer of light for the other Republicans
column2: who hold out hope that despite Trump's strong standing in the polls
column3: there are some signs the race is fluid.

column1: Those surveyed in the Suffolk poll
column2: for instance
column3: are split 48%-44% when asked whether Trump's nomination was inevitable or whether some other candidate could win the nomination.

column1: Nearly 4 in 10 said they might change their minds before the January primary.
But the Trump base is fiercely loyal
column2: with 84% saying their minds were made up to back him and just 15% saying they might switch to someone else.

column1: “I know a lot of people don't like him. I don't like his personality. I think it stinks
column2: said Ronald Sassi, of Chichester, N.H., who wants Trump to win. But he doesn't have any lobbyists telling him what he has to be or beholden to them."

column1: Jo-Ann Jacob
column2: an independent from Exeter
column3: N.H.
column4: doesn't want to rush in making a choice before she gets a chance to hear from more candidates.

column1: Several of the Republican contenders are "too much" in the sense they brag about themselves or insult others. She prefers the more somber style of North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum or former Vice President Mike Pence
column2: who she describes as more "down to Earth."

column1: Both men are in the basement of the polling at 1%
column2: according to the Suffolk University survey.

column1: Other independent voters
column2: who can participate in the New Hampshire GOP primary
column3: said they aren't sure what to make of the current field yet.

column1: “At this point
column2: I'm really unsure
column3: ” Lynne Chase
column4: a registered nurse who lives in Grantham
column5: N.H.
column6: told USA TODAY.

column1: Chase
column2: who identifies as an independent
column3: said she has "deep concerns" about the country's partisan divide
column4: and how
column5: "this is the pool that we have to select from."

column1:
That's why I choose to remain a middle ground voter,” she said.
Other voters said they are drawn toward Haley and Burgum because of their experience and record as their state's chief executive.
“When you govern a state, you have a lot of experience in governing within a structure of government,” Patricia Squires, a Republican from Wolfeboro, N.H., told USA TODAY.
Many voters shared how they aren't crazy about the prospect of a Trump-Biden rematch in 2024, but don't see a way to change that probability.
Rachel McKaig, a Democrat, said there is a general frustration that President Joe Biden will be the party’s likely nominee come next November.   
“I genuinely wish we had another candidate,” said McKaig, a University of New Hampshire graduate. I just can't see him doing anything amazing over the next four years
column2: because he hasn't done anything amazing in the past four years.”

column1: Given its status as the "first-in-the-nation primary
column2:
New Hampshire draws a fair amount of out-of-state visitors.
Those voters said they were impressed with lesser-known candidates they had a chance to see in-person, but admit there is an underlying pessimism that makes it hard for others to take that contender seriously.
“I just know that you look at the people who are ascending because that tends to continue, said John Sweeny
column3: a retired appellate judge who came to New Hampsire from Hudson Valley in New York.

column1: The ones who were staying flat – it would take a miracle for something to happen that they're going to say, ‘Oh, wow, you're wonderful. I didn't notice you before. Let me pay attention to you now,’ he added. "It just doesn't happen."
Shawn Rieke
column2: a retired technician from Johnstown
column3: Colo. who is vacationing in New England
column4: waited outside the old State House for a glimpse of DeSantis after he filed.

column1: People may not like Trump's "crudeness" or the personal attacks he makes
column2: but they agree with him on many issues
column3: he said. They also think the criminal charges against him are politically motivated.

column1: At this point it looks like it's pretty much locked up, Rieke said. "It is what it is."
Republican Rachel Hannah Swift
column3: who comes from Hagerstown
column4: Maryland said no one is happy with the prospect of a Biden-Trump re-match
column5: and she has a unique response: Running for president herself.

column1: As her colorful car blared pop music outside of the old State House
column2: Swift said: "These politicians are kinda boring...They don't have a lot going on. I'm going to beat both of them."

column1: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell hinted Thursday that the central bank may hold interest rates steady next month amid rising long-term bond yields that could curtail economic growth
column2: effectively doing the work of another rate hike.

column1: At the same time
column2: Powell said that an economy and labor market that continue to run hot could prompt the Fed to raise rates again at some point.

column1: “Financial conditions have tightened significantly in recent months
column2: and longer-term bond yields have been an important driving factor in this tightening
column3: ” Powell said in written remarks he planned to deliver at the Economic Club of New York at noon. “We remain attentive to these developments because persistent changes in financial conditions can have implications for the path of monetary policy.”

column1: The yield in the 10-year Treasury bond has shot up to 4.9% from 3.2% in March because of a stronger-than-expected economy that could push inflation higher and a large increase in the supply of Treasuries linked to federal government infrastructure and other spending. That's the highest level since 2007.

The rise in Treasury yields has pushed up 30-year mortgage rates close to 8% and driven up borrowing costs for corporations. Those developments will likely further dampen the housing market and hobble business investment.
“Given the uncertainties and risks
column2: and how far we have come
column3: (the Fed’s policymaking committee) is proceeding carefully
column4: ” Powell added.

column1: The Fed has raised its key short-term interest rate by 5.25 percentage points since early last year to fight a historic inflation spike. Recently
column2: however
column3: Powell has said the Fed will move more cautiously since the risk of failing to subdue inflation and causing a recession by hiking rates too aggressively are more balanced.

column1: “Doing too little could allow above-target inflation to become entrenched and ultimately require monetary policy to ring more persistent inflation from the economy at a high cost to employment
column2: ” Powell said in his written remarks Thursday. “Doing too much could also do unnecessary harm to the economy.”

column1: Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee and Philadelphia Fed chief Patrick Harker both have said the central bank should halt its rate increases.
Yet Powell also noted that economic and job growth have been surprisingly strong recently and that could stall further progress on inflation
column2: which he said has fallen notably.

column1: “Additional evidence of persistently above-trend growth
column2: or that tightness in the labor market is no longer easing
column3: could put further progress on inflation at risk and could warrant further tightening of monetary policy
column4: ” Powell said.

column1: In a research note
column2: Barclays said it expects the Fed to stand pat in November but hike rates again in mid-December. Fed officials are slated to make a decision on rates at the close of a two-day meeting on Nov. 1.

column1: Powell noted that the Fed’s preferred inflation measure
column2: which strips out volatile food and energy costs
column3: is projected to fall 3.7% for September from a peak of 5.6% in early 2022. Still
column4: he added
column5: tht”inflation is still too high
column6: and a few months of good data are only the beginning of what it will take to build confidence that inflation is moving down sustainably to our (2%) goal.”

column1: He also said the labor market is “gradually cooling
column2: ” with the number of job openings falling from record levels and wage growth easing.  Still employers added a booming 336
column3: 000 jobs in September.

column1: And the economy has been resilient despite high inflation and interest rates. Gross domestic product is expected to have increased at a healthy 3.5% annual rate in the third quarter
column2: according to a survey by Wolters Kluwer Blue Chip Economic Indicators. That follows growth of just above 2% the first half of the year.

column1: “The record suggests that a sustainable return to our 2% inflation goal is likely to require a period of below trend growth and some further softening in labor market conditions
column2: ” Powell said.

column1: Cheetos has its own take on the traditional pretzels and cheese sauce snack: new Cheetos Pretzels.
The treat
column2: now hitting stores
column3: comes in two flavors: Cheetos Pretzels Cheddar and Cheetos Pretzels Flamin' Hot.

column1: Each piece has one side that looks like pretzel
column2: made of crispy wheat
column3: while the other is covered in "Cheetle" powdered cheese flavor.

column1: They can be purchased at stores nationwide for $5.69 in 10-ounce bags and $2.49 in 3-ounce bags.
Cheetos isn't a newbie when it comes to experimenting with new combinations. Three years ago its Cheetos Mac 'n Cheese received a lot of attention and launched in three flavors: Bold & Cheesy
column2: Flamin’ Hot and Cheesy Jalapeño.

column1: Mac and cheese ... ice cream?:Kraft Mac & Cheese ice cream is back at Walmart next week along with six new flavors by Van Leeuwen
If you are a Cheetos junkie

column3: plus all these different flavors of Cheetos: Flamin’ Hot Smoky Ghost Pepper
column4: White Cheddar Bag of Bones
column5: Cinnamon Sugar Bag of Bones
column6: Crunchy Nashville Hot
column7: and Crunchy Flamin’ Hot Tangy Chili Fusion.

column1: Cheetos' parent company Frito-Lay decided to venture into pretzel territory because it found 63% of Cheetos consumers were also buying pretzels and that flavored pretzels have been driving 58% of the pretzel sales growth.
Our fans are always hungry for unique ways that they can experience Cheetos' signature cheesy flavor, which is why this latest innovation is breaking into an entirely new category, said Tina Mahal
column2: Frito-Lay's senior vice president of marketing
column3: in a press release. "Cheetos pretzels maximize the fan-favorite seasoning in each bite with the perfect product texture
column4: ultimately bringing the Cheetos flavor experience to life in pretzel form."

Federal safety regulators are recalling tens of thousands of gun safes after they say a child died accessing a firearm inside of one.
According to the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) and Fortress Safe
column2: the recall involves about 61
column3: 000 biometric gun safes because of a safety hazard and risk of death caused by a programming feature that
column4: in more than three dozen instances
column5: allowed unauthorized access to the safes.

column1: The recalled safes
column2: which were made in China
column3: were imported and distributed by Xpedition LLC
column4: dba Fortress Safe
column5: of Naperville
column6: Illinois.

column1: Consumers can believe they have properly programmed the biometric feature when in fact the safe remains in the default to open mode, which can allow unauthorized users, including children, to access the safe to remove hazardous contents, including firearms, the CPSC posted in its Thursday recall.
So far
column2: CPSC said
column3: at least one death has been tied to the issue that prompted the recall.

column1: The agency said "it is aware of a recent lawsuit" claiming a 12-year-old boy died from a firearm obtained from one of the recalled safes. The CPSC did not release additional details about the child's death.
As of Thursday
column2: the agency said
column3: there had been 39 incidents of consumers reporting their safes were accessed by "unpaired" fingerprints.

column1: Drug
column2: medical device recall:Family Dollar issues huge recall for over-the-counter drugs
column3: medical devices in 23 states

column1: The CPSC reported the recalled gun safes are portable lock boxes
column2: personal safes
column3: pistol vaults
column4: and gun cabinets with brand names Fortress
column5: Cabela’s
column6: Gettysburg
column7: and Legend Range & Field.

column1: Nine models are being recalled:
Safes being recalled were sold at the following stores: Bass Pro Shops
column2: Cabela’s
column3: Scheel’s
column4: Sportsman’s Guide
column5: Optics Planet
column6: Dick’s Sporting Goods
column7: Gander
column8: Rural King
column9: Lowe’s and online at Amazon.com and Ebay.com.

column1: Retailers sold the safes
column2: manufactured in China
column3: from January 2019 through this month.

column1: The safes sold between $44 and $290
column2: the CPSC reported.

column2: 000 vehicles recalled

column1: Consumer should "immediately stop using the biometric feature
column2: remove the batteries from the safe
column3: and only use the key for the recalled safes being used to store firearms
column4:
the agency said.
For instructions on how to disable the biometric feature and get a free replacement safe contact Fortress Safes.
Natalie Neysa Alund is a senior reporter for USA TODAY. Reach her at nalund@usatoday.com and follow her on X @nataliealund.
An Oregon man may have missed winning the second-largest Powerball lottery ever by one number, but he still walked away with a $1 million prize.
77-year-old Thomas Willard told Oregon Lottery officials he only plays when the jackpots grow to large amounts. He purchased his ticket for the Oct. 9 drawing at the 7 Star Convenience Store in Mill City, a small city about 32 miles east of Oregon's capital, Salem.
The convenience store will receive a $100,000 commission for selling a winning ticket.
A winning ticket sold in California from the next drawing on Oct. 11 claimed the $1.76 billion Powerball jackpot.
At our age

column1: Ahhh. Days at the beach. It’s a perfect day – the crisp air
column2: light breeze
column3: warm sun – oh
column4: and most importantly
column5: your hair looks fantastic. If you have ever liked the “beachy waves” look of your hair after a quick dip in the ocean – you’re in luck! There are many different sea salt sprays available so you can look like you’re coming straight from the beach
column6: no matter where you are.

column1: So what are sea salt sprays? What are they made out of? Are there any downsides? How long do they last
column2: and what do they cost? We answer all of your burning questions about this handy styling product.

column1: It’s not seawater. But it does contain salt and other minerals like magnesium or potassium. There’s also
column2: usually
column3: a fragrance associated with it.

column1: These sprays are designed to mimic the way your hair looks after getting out of the ocean. Since seawater contains a high amount of salt
column2: so does sea salt spray. The reason your hair gets curly after getting out of the ocean or using sea salt spray is that the salt pulls moisture out of the hair. The result is that the hair strands begin to lift – just enough to reveal a slightly curly pattern.

column1: It will stay put until you wash it out. To rephrase: the minerals will stay on your hair until you wash it out. However
column2: the style will likely not stay put for more than a day without the use of a standard hairspray.

column1: Is sea salt good for you? How it compares to other salts and how to watch your sodium
Everyone could benefit from sea salt spray if they are looking to style their hair in beachy curls. However
column2: people with oily hair can especially benefit from sea salt spray
column3: as the minerals may soak up some of the oil.

column1: It depends on the brand and the amount of spray you buy. The range is generally $6 to $50.
Too much sea salt spray (or exposure to seawater) can dehydrate or damage your hair. You can combat dehydrated hair with a moisturizing shampoo and conditioner.
Overall
column2: sea salt spray is a safe and stylish choice for your hair!

column2: you may not be the first to know. It's a commonly held belief that dogs can sense pregnancy. Some say they even see changes in their pup's behavior before they even know themselves that they are pregnant.

column2: if there is any

column1: Here's what Dr. Camille Alander

column1: While there is no hard scientific backing to the idea
column2: Alander does say that it bodes well for the theory that dogs can sense cancer
column3: decreases in blood sugar
column4: and can help find missing people.

column1: Dogs have an absolutely incredible sense of smell, she said
column2: so it's not out of the realm of possibility that with the hormone changes caused by pregnancy
column3: a canine might be able to sniff out the condition.

column1: People absolutely have reported that they knew they were pregnant because their dog began to act differently
column2: Alander said. She jokes that signs from your pup should not be used in lieu of a pregnancy test.

column1: Do dogs dream?:Here's why they may be dreaming about you
A lot of people report that dogs will become more clingy or more protective
column2: Alander said.

column1: In a sitting setting
column2: which is where most of Bond Vet's clinics are located
column3: clients have reported that after pregnancy
column4: their dog would become difficult to walk
column5: she said
column6: trying to attack nearly every other dog that passed by.

column1: Alander also offered up the example of a dog following their owner to the shower in the morning and sitting outside the door until they were done. She described the change in behavior mostly as "subtle things that other people probably wouldn't notice as a change
column2: but because you know your pet well you would probably pick up on."

column1: Cats have a strong sense of smell just as dogs do
column2: but are not often used in cadaver detection or other pursuits in the same way because they are not as trainable

column1: It's not out of the question in terms of pregnancy though

column1: Cars making loud noises are never a good sign and are a particular hassle when the cause of the noise is a missing catalytic converter.
Catalytic converters are regularly targeted car parts
column2: sometimes stolen right out of driveways. This month
column3: three members of a California family pleaded guilty to their roles in a $600 million catalytic converter theft ring
column4: USA TODAY previously reported.

column1: The theft can cause car owners headaches and up to thousands of dollars. What are catalytic converters
column2: and why are they stolen so often?

column1: Catalytic converters are your car’s way of filtering out harmful engine exhaust pollutants. This exhaust system converts pollutants (hydrocarbons
column2: carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides) into compounds that already make up our atmosphere (nitrogen
column3: oxygen
column4: carbon dioxide and water).

column1: Well-designed catalytic converters can reduce hydrocarbon and carbon monoxide emissions by about 90%
column2: as well as Diesel Particulate Matter emissions by 25-35%. These converters work by using metallic catalysts to drive reactions at lower temperatures than would normally be needed.

column1: Per guidelines from the Environmental Protection Agency
column2: cars made in or after 1975 have catalytic converters to curb pollutants. According to the EPA
column3: starting in 1988
column4: anyone installing or selling a catalytic converter that hasn’t met federal guidelines may face penalties of up to $25
column5: 000 for each installation.

column1: Some states have even adopted stricter environmental protections for catalytic converters. The California Air Resources Board requires CARB-compliant catalytic converters
column2: which use an enhanced process to meet the stricter standards for curbing harmful emissions. California and Colorado require all cars to use CARB-compliant catalytic converters. The state of New York requires cars made in 1993
column4: 1996 and newer to use the converters
column5: and Maine mandates CARB-compliant catalytic converters for cars made in and after 2001.

column1: Catalytic converter thefts are up:How to protect yours from being stolen
Reported catalytic converter thefts increased by 325% between 2019 and 2020. The reason for stolen converters is the explanation behind any theft — money. The rhodium
column2: palladium and platinum used in these parts are valuable
column3: and rhodium can go for $20
column4: 000 per ounce
column5: according to the National Insurance Crime Bureau. Palladium costs nearly $3
column6: 000 per ounce
column7: and platinum costs about $1
column8: 128 per ounce.

column1: Twenty-six states proposed bills in 2021 to prevent catalytic converter theft
column2: with 10 states passing legislation.

column1: NICB recommends taking precautions to prevent your catalytic converter from getting stolen:
If your catalytic converter was stolen
column2: you may get an engine error code from your vehicle. Because the converter muffles the exhaust sound
column3: you also will notice a louder
column4: unusual sound coming from the exhaust
column5: TheMotorGuy.com reports.

column1: While driving without a catalytic converter is technically possible
column2: you may run into legal issues if you live in a state where emissions tests are required to use the vehicle. Federal law also prohibits the removal of catalytic converters.

column1: Prices vary when it comes to replacement converters because of the fit of the part. Universal replacements can cost about $200-$300 according to AutoZone
column2: but newer vehicles may require direct-fit converters because the original catalytic converters are incorporated into the exhaust manifold. These direct-fit converters can cost as much as $2

column1: Electric and hybrid car sales are on the rise as the Biden administration proposes tougher greenhouse gas emissions for cars and trucks sold in the U.S. Nearly 98 thousand hybrid vehicles were sold in the U.S. in April 2023
column2: which is up over 36% from last year
column3: the U.S. Department of Energy’s Argonne National Library reports.

column1: Even more popular are plug-in vehicles – over 105 thousand were sold in April 2023
column2: a number that includes both battery electric vehicles and plug-in hybrid vehicles.

column1: Here’s everything you need to know about the different types of hybrid cars.
Hybrid electric vehicles
column2: also known as HEVs
column3: use an internal combustion engine and electric motors to run. These cars are appropriately named because they are a cross between a gasoline car
column4: which runs on a combustion engine
column5: and an electric car
column6: which uses a battery-operated electric motor.

column1: There are three main types of HEVs:
PHEVs are often more expensive than mild or full hybrid vehicles
column2: but they generally produce lower levels of emissions because they can run solely on electricity for longer. According to the DOE
column3: current commercially available PHEVs have an electric range of 15 to 60 miles or more.

column1: Latest car recalls:Nissan
column2: Kia
column3: Mercedes-Benz
column4: Ford and more

column1: HEVs use an internal combustion engine and battery-powered electric motor to get the desired result of high fuel economy and low emissions. This is because the extra power from the electric motor allows for a smaller combustion engine.
PHEVs mostly run on electricity
column2: but they have an internal combustion engine that powers the vehicle when the battery is low or when electricity is being used heavily elsewhere in the car
column3: like in heating or air conditioning.

column1: There are two main methods of designing hybrid vehicles. Parallel hybrids connect the engine and electric motor to the wheels through mechanical coupling
column2: according to the DOE
column3: while series hybrids use the electric motor exclusively to drive the wheels.

column1: Typically no – hybrid cars do not need to be charged. Plug-in hybrid vehicles can be charged with charging equipment but also use other methods outside of electric charging to keep the vehicle running.

Other types of hybrid cars do not need to be charged at all and cannot be plugged in. The battery in a hybrid car is charged through both the internal combustion engine and a process called “regenerative braking
column2: ” when the vehicle’s electric motor acts as a generator and captures energy typically lost during braking.
