column1: We found room for both hope and pessimism in a recent free expression survey that the University of Chicago helped develop with The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research. One of the most worrying results was that not everyone is seen as having the same freedom to speak their minds on college campuses.
People said conservatives had the least freedom to speak
column2: but they perceived problems of exclusion beyond just one group. Asian people also were seen as having less freedom of expression than other groups
column3: and respondents said campuses did the worst at providing an inclusive environment for conservatives
column4: visiting speakers
column5: Asian people and transgender people.

column1: We see related problems for campus expression as people respond to the tragedies of the Israel-Hamas war. Many students don’t feel free to express their views
column2: and some universities risk chilling discussions on their campuses by taking collective positions
column3: sending the message that there is one “official” stance and other opinions are not welcome.

column1: That is a troubling trend in our polarized times. We face huge challenges as a society
column2: and we can’t address them fully if people at colleges and universities – our greatest engines of new thinking and innovation – do not feel free to challenge each other and pursue ideas and breakthroughs wherever they lead.

column1: Sadly
column2: just as the need for new knowledge and discovery becomes more acute
column3: universities have been riddled with challenges to free inquiry from all ideological factions. We find ourselves in something of a moral panic
column4: from which neither the left nor the right is immune.

column1: But we also see signs that the tide is turning
column2: and fast. Our survey found heartening public support for many aspects of free expression
column3: including bipartisan resistance to state restrictions on what professors at public universities can teach.

column1: Among the encouraging stands that universities are taking on free expression
column2: Cornell University in Ithaca
column3: New York
column4: this year rejected a call for mandatory trigger warnings for potentially offensive course content. In Northern California
column5: Stanford Law Dean Jenny Martinez
column6: who wrote an articulate defense of free expression after the disruption of a talk by U.S. Circuit Judge Kyle Duncan
column7: was appointed provost of the university.

column1: Many schools – including our own – are launching new free inquiry and expression initiatives
column2: while others have adopted the “Chicago Principles” on free expression.

column1: Biden is too old. And so is Trump.As a Gen Z voter
column2: I want younger candidates.

column1: Such bold moves are critical
column2: but they go only so far. To realize the potential of free inquiry we need an active shift in campus culture.

column1: The project of free inquiry and expression is about much more than solitary acts of expression – it’s about unlocking the power of discovery and knowledge in the context of an academic community to address major challenges and promote the flourishing of knowledge.
Freedom of expression on college campuses is not the same as an absence of personal constraint on speech
column2: nor is it grounded primarily on the First Amendment.

column1: Universities are crucibles of truth-seeking
column2: for faculties and students alike. To advance that ideal
column3: they must be places where students and scholars are challenged by alternative viewpoints.

column1: Don't let Israel-Hamas war divide US.We need to cooperate across our differences.
Universities have it in their power to take concrete steps to build stronger cultures of free inquiry and expression
column2: including:

column1: Despite the challenges to free inquiry
column2: we remain enthusiastic about the breakthroughs of human ingenuity and discovery that our colleges and universities will yet make possible. They can’t happen soon enough.

column1: Combining the remarkable burgeoning activity across the higher education landscape with the creativity and passion of Generation Z makes for a very bright future.
Doubling down on free inquiry and expression is the key. Without it
column2: universities will lose all that makes them distinctive.

column1: Tom Ginsburg is a professor of law at the University of Chicago and the inaugural faculty director of the university’s Forum for Free Inquiry and Expression; Tony Banout is the forum’s inaugural executive director.

column1: While the Biden administration was still floating trial balloons regarding support of Israel after the Hamas terrorist attack on Oct. 7
column2: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis was making concrete plans to help get Americans trapped in Israel out of harm’s way. More than 30 U.S. citizens have died in the war.

column1: When times are tough
column2: DeSantis is a guy you want to have on your side.

column1: Last Thursday
column2: he issued an executive order that authorized the emergency response to fly Floridians out of Israel. In the order
column3: DeSantis argued that the Biden administration had been too slow in its effort to get Americans to safety – and that commercial flights had been grounded given the violence in the region.

column1: Just days later
column2: on Sunday night
column3: a flight of 270 Americans – more than 90 of them children – landed in Tampa on “DeSantis Airlines
column4: ” as some have dubbed the effort. DeSantis was on the ground to greet the evacuees.

column1: The relief and gratitude on the passengers’ faces were palpable. And they won’t have to pay the state back – unlike U.S. citizens who call on the federal government to get them out of Israel (which is apparently customary in such instances). Late last week
column2: the State Department began arranging charter flights for Americans stranded in Israel.

column1: More than 300 citizens have returned home to Florida
column2: thanks to the governor – and Project Dynamo
column3: the rescue nonprofit that coordinated the flights.

column1: Florida is home to one of the largest Jewish populations in the world
column2: as well as many dual Israeli American citizens with family in Israel
column3: according to the executive order. DeSantis press secretary Jeremy Redfern told me the rescue mission has cost about $4 million so far and more flights are expected in the days ahead.

column1: President Joe Biden should send DeSantis a thank-you card. He’s not likely to
column2: however
column3: because DeSantis does actively want Biden’s job.

column1: DeSantis as governor is impressive
column2: as he has proved during several natural disasters in Florida
column3: as well as effectively running the state government. When things need to get done
column4: that’s when he shines.

column1: The presidential campaign trail and finding his voice on the national stage have proved more challenging for him. After an initial surge in the polls
column2: DeSantis has struggled to maintain his No. 2 spot behind GOP presidential front-runner and former President Donald Trump.

column1: Bipartisan corruption scandals:Sure
column2: GOP Rep. George Santos is bad news. But Democratic Sen. Bob Menendez is much worse.

column1: The Florida governor seems to be hitting his stride now
column2: leaning into the leadership qualities that make him an attractive candidate. We need less of the forced culture warrior and more of the capable governor.

column1: DeSantis also is bolder in his attacks on Trump
column2: and that’s a positive sign. He called out Trump’s poorly thought out comments last week
column3: when the former president slammed Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for not being prepared for the attack and called Hezbollah militants “very smart.” It was supposed to be an indirect criticism of Biden
column4: but was typical of Trump’s crass and cringeworthy style.

column1: “Now is not the time to be attacking our ally
column2: ” DeSantis said in New Hampshire last week.

column1: He added: “If you want to change from Trump
column2: I think I’m the best leader.”

column1: DeSantis’ ability to deliver hundreds of Floridians safely home from Israel is a welcome contrast with the chaos on display among Republicans in the U.S. House in recent weeks.
After a small faction of the party ousted Speaker Kevin McCarthy without having a clue whom they wanted to replace him
column2: the House has been paralyzed in its ability to send aid to Israel after the attack. Not to mention the upcoming fight over funding the government.

column1: It’s all been a very bad look for Republicans

column1: And most important

column1: In excerpts of her upcoming memoir
column2: shared by People
column3: Britney Spears wrote that she became pregnant with Justin Timberlake’s baby and had an abortion because he wasn’t ready to become a father.

column1: “Justin definitely wasn’t happy about the pregnancy. He said we weren’t ready to have a baby in our lives
column2: that we were way too young
column3: ” Spears writes in her book
column4: according to People. "If it had been left up to me alone
column5: I never would have done it. And yet Justin was so sure that he didn’t want to be a father."

column1: “To this day
column2: ” Spears continues
column3: “it’s one of the most agonizing things I have ever experienced in my life."

column1: Spears’ statements underscore the benefits that male partners receive from having access to abortion care — an often overlooked aspect of reproductive health in light of Roe v. Wade’s downfall last year that
column2: if ignored in society and politics alike
column3: perpetuates the idea that abortion is solely a women’s issue.

column1: “Abortion is a highly stigmatized form of healthcare
column2: and women almost always bear the brunt of the stigma and shame around abortion
column3: ” said Bethany Everett
column4: an associate professor of sociology at the University of Utah. “Yet
column5: there are likely many people
column6: including male partners
column7: who don’t want to become parents or have another child
column8: who also benefit from abortion access — benefits that are rarely recognized by the broader public or policy makers.”

column1: Everett
column2: who studies the social and political implications of reproductive health
column3: said Spears' claim that Timberlake did not want to become a parent suggests he was aware that a child could “derail his career
column4: ” a reality that “men rarely publicly acknowledge” but is critical to recognize in a post-Roe world.

column1: (On June 24
column3: the Supreme Court overturned the constitutional right to abortion
column4: leaving it up to states to determine its legality. Some states have since banned nearly all abortions
column5: while others have passed legislation protecting abortion access.)

column1: Timberlake has yet to publicly respond to Spears’ comments.
Andréa Becker
column2: a medical sociologist and postdoctoral research fellow with the University of California San Francisco’s Advancing New Standards in Reproductive Health program
column3: said this example is “consistent with the literature
column4: ” in that “men don’t necessarily have to come forward and tell their abortion stories if they don’t want to.”

column1: This pattern is due in part to a lack of research analyzing how access to abortion impacts male partners
column2: a shortfall that Becker said “reinforces the way we talk about birth control
column3: condom use and pregnancy avoidance as a woman’s responsibility and issue.”

column1: “We just forget about the sperm involved in creating a pregnancy
column2: ” Becker said.

column1: As a result
column2: stigmas associated with abortion disproportionately impact women.

column1: “Men are rarely acknowledged as beneficiaries from abortion access so it is much easier for them to avoid the stigma and shame around abortion if they don’t think it’s something that impacts them personally
column2: ” Everett said.

column1: Data show that 1 in 5 men in the U.S. have been involved in abortion
column2: which researchers say is likely an undercount. It's estimated that about 1 in 4 women in the U.S. will have an abortion by age of 45
column3: according to the Guttmacher Institute.

column1: The total number of abortions in the U.S. is difficult to measure
column2: but the most recent estimates from 2020 show that there were anywhere between 620
column5: according to data from the CDC and Guttmacher Institute. (The number of abortions in the U.S. dropped immediately after the fall of Roe v. Wade.)

column1: Meanwhile
column2: research has found that some men are hesitant to admit their involvement with abortion. In a 2022 study
column3: men were less likely to disclose the fact they were involved in an abortion during face-to-face interviews compared to an online survey.

column1: In one of the few studies to analyze how abortion impacts male partners
column2: Everett found that men who impregnated someone as a teenager were more likely to pursue post-high school education and graduate from college when the pregnancy ended in abortion compared to those that ended in live birth.

column1: More on maternal health care inequities:Inequities in maternal health care access are not new. They have deep roots in history.
“When men don’t speak up
column2: the burden of having to make decisions about unplanned pregnancies and access to abortion falls exclusively on women — and that’s an equity issue
column3: ” said Dr. Brian Nguyen
column4: an associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Southern California’s Keck School of Medicine. Nguyen runs a research group called the EMERGE Lab that conducts studies aimed at ensuring men recognize their responsibility in women’s reproductive health and gender equity.

column1: While questions still abound about what role male partners should have in the abortion landscape
column2: it’s important to recognize the general lack of knowledge about abortion in the U.S.
column3: particularly among some men
column4: Becker said. Consequently
column5: research shows many policy decisions now in place threaten the lives of women and girls who would benefit from abortion care
column6: especially for people of color
column7: migrants
column8: people with disabilities
column9: and those living on low incomes or in rural areas.

column1:
Men do have a place in advocating for reproductive rights,” Everett said. “They can donate to abortion funds and reproductive health care organizations, and, importantly, with the consent of their partners, acknowledge how abortion access has benefited them.”
This is the third story in a series exploring grief, how people face it, cope with it and heal from it.
Click here to read the first installment: This family went through an unimaginable tragedy. How YouTube helped. And here for the second: At 25 she found out she had the breast cancer gene. Now, she's grieving motherhood.
Lisa Bowman had everything going for her − until she didn't.
The now 56-year-old was the global chief marketing officer for United Way. United Way, an education, economic mobility and health-focused nonprofit, recruited her.
What should've been a dream job spiraled into a nightmare: she alleged she was sexually harassed at work, and more than 20 former employees of the company said sexual harassment
column2: discrimination and retaliation is commonplace
column3:
at the company, according to a 2021 HuffPost report. The nonprofit fired Bowman in January 2020, months after she reported the harassment. Multiple claims have been filed with the EEOC; United Way told USA TODAY it doesn't comment on matters of employment. The CEO of United Way resigned as the chaos swirled.
But Bowman didn't just lose her job. She lost much more.
The loss of my job was really that loss of my identity
column4: she says. All of a sudden
column5: I went from being Lisa Bowman
column6: CMO of the world's largest nonprofit where anybody would take my call
column7: people were beating down the door to talk to me
column8: to all of a sudden just being Lisa Bowman
column9: private citizen
column11: so to speak. And that was a really
column12: really tough thing for me to navigate."

column1: Grief doesn't apply to death alone. It comes in a series of shapes and sizes different than you might expect. And all can coexist. (You can share yours with us at the bottom of this article).
There's room enough in the world for all these losses, and one doesn't take away from the other, says David Kessler
column2: grief expert and founder of Grief.com.

column1: Bowman says her grief affected her as a woman: "When I talk about the grief over the loss of a job
column2: I think for women
column3: as we fight so hard sometimes to get to executive levels
column4: and those C-suite positions
column5: when we get there
column6: that job becomes an integral part of our identity
column7: she says. And so we identify very closely with our role."

column1: She attempted to push through her grief – a "fake it 'til you make it" mentality – the same way she dealt with it at 26 following the death of her mother.

She never got to see certain things happen in my life. She wasn't there for a wedding, for example, or to see the career trajectory that I ended up with, which have largely been influenced by her, Bowman says. "And in some cases
column2: this is kind of the same thing. I'm missing out on all of those things
column3: because of this loss of a job. And that in and of itself – it's grief. Every time something happens
column4: and I have a financial challenge
column5: it brings it all back."

column1: Bowman confided in friends and family in lieu of professional help. While none could relate to her quandary
column2: they listened to her. Heard her cry.

column1: She later poured those thoughts into a book – "Harasshole" – which
column2: while therapeutic
column3: made it that much harder for her to get a job. Bowman previously had a 15-year stint in executive-level marketing roles at UPS but now freelances.

column1: It's made it very, very difficult for me to find employment, she says. "I have candidly applied for over 1000 jobs. I've had people tell me that they would love to hire me and they can't
column2: because they can't take a risk with me. I've had job offers rescinded when people have found out about this."

column1: Another kind of grief: missed opportunities.
Bowman's grief is not more or less than any other type of grief. "There's a context to think about it
column2: as sometimes we approach grief like it's a pie
column3: Kessler says. And it goes wrong if we think
column4: Wait
column5: wait
column6: you're taking some of the pie on your job loss. But I need a lot of it because my spouse died. And that isn't how grief works."

column1: Some might call Bowman's job loss "disenfranchised grief" – a loss not openly acknowledged
column2: socially mourned or publicly supported
column3: according to Loree Johnson
column4: a licensed marriage and family therapist. It's grief felt on an individual level not necessarily seen by others.

column1: Plus
column2: "the emotions can be the same
column3: regarding all kinds of loss
column4: says Amy Morin, psychotherapist and the host of a podcast. Someone who lost their job may feel sad
column5: anxious
column6: and a bit disoriented
column7: which might be the same feelings someone experiences when they lose a friend or relative."

column1: Read next:At 25 she found out she had the breast cancer gene. Now
column2: she's grieving motherhood.

column1: Today
column2: Bowman's grief hasn't dissipated. It's morphed: "Similar to the loss of a person
column3: the grief doesn't go away. It's just that you get used to carrying it. So it doesn't feel quite as heavy."

column1: For those going through a similar crisis
column2: Bowman offers these words of advice: "You have to realize that it's not your role that defines who you are. It's who you are that makes you you. It's your skills
column3: it's your capabilities
column4: it's the value you provide."

column2: and she felt alone. In her grief
column3: she found YouTube.

column1: Most people are familiar with the sweet flavor and soft texture of the banana – but some may wonder about its nutritional value – like its upsides

column4: MSRD
column5: LDN
column6: CDCES
column7: Registered Nutritionist and Certified Diabetes Educator at Pritikin Longevity Center to find out everything you need to know about bananas.

column1: Although bananas have many benefits
column2: there are three main nutritional benefits that we want to focus on.

column1: Are you getting enough potassium?Here's what to know about the mineral
column2: how to get more

column1: The main drawback of bananas is the sugar content. Even though it is natural
column2: too much sugar can lead to issues
column3: particularly if you’re a diabetic or if you have weight loss goals.

column1: Burnstine explains
column2: “All fruits are not created equal in terms of calories and sugar content. Although the sugar content in fruit is natural and preferred

column4: for example
column5: berries."

column1: She adds
column2: “Those with digestive disorders may have trouble digesting the sugars in the banana and they can cause some GI distress. It's a good idea to eat the banana before it gets all spotted like a leopard. The more spotted
column3: the more ripened the banana becomes and increases the sugar content of the banana.”

column1: Burnstine says the short answer is: yes. However
column2: she urges you to think about some of the caveats

column1: “Keep the portions small
column2: have them with fibrous foods like vegetables
column3: and/or pair them with a healthy protein or plant-based fat to increase satiety and dilute sugar concentration.” She gives some examples of what she does at her practice
column4: “Some great pairings would be Greek yogurt with a banana or a handful of nuts with a banana.”

column1: Additionally
column2: the American Heart Association recommends
column3: “Don’t go bananas. But maybe eat one.” They concurred that bananas have lots of wonderful nutrients

column1: WASHINGTON (AP) — A multimillion-dollar conspiracy trial that stretched across the worlds of politics and entertainment is now touching on the tech world with arguments that a defense attorney for a Fugees rapper bungled closing arguments by using an artificial intelligence program.
Prakazrel "Pras" Michel
column3: argued that the use of the "experimental" generative AI program was one of a number of errors made by his "unqualified
column4: unprepared and ineffectual" trial attorney before his conviction earlier this year
column5: according to a motion for new trial his new lawyers filed this week. The company behind the program
column6: on the other hand
column7: said it was a tool used to help write closing statements
column8: and a harbinger of major changes in the field.

column1: Generative AI programs are capable of creating realistic text
column2: images and video. They're raising tough questions about misinformation and copyright protections as well as industry calls for regulations in Congress. Programs like ChatGPT have already had ripple effects across professions like writing and education. The arguments in the Michel case could preview issues to come as the technology makes a rapid advance.

column1: The Grammy-winning rapper's trial was touted as the first time generative AI was used in a federal trial in a news release from the startup company that designed the system. Defense attorney David Kenner
column2: well known for his previous representation of rappers like Suge Knight and Snoop Dogg
column3: also gave a quote calling the system a "game changer for complex litigation."

column1: But in his last words to the jury
column2: Kenner appeared to mix up key elements of the case and misattributed the lyric "Every single day
column3: every time I pray
column4: I will be missing you
column5:
to the Fugees, the 1990s hip-hop group his client co-founded, when actually it is a well-known line from a song by the rapper Diddy, then known as Puff Daddy, court documents from Michel's new attorney, Peter Zeidenberg, stated.
Kenner did not respond to a phone call and email seeking comment from The Associated Press. The company, EyeLevel.AI, said the program wasn't experimental" but instead trained using only facts from the case
column6: including court transcripts
column7: not musical lyrics or anything found online. It's intended to provide fast answers to complex questions to help
column8: not replace
column9: human lawyers
column10: said co-founder and COO Neil Katz.

column1: We think AI technology is gong to completely revolutionize the legal field by making it faster and cheaper to get complex answers to legal questions and research, Katz said.
He denied an allegation from Michel's new lawyers that Kenner appeared to have a financial interest in the program.
The case will likely be closely watched as more law firms adopt the technology
column2: said Sharon Nelson
column3: president of Sensei Enterprises
column4: a digital forensics
column5: cybersecurity and information technology firm. A substantial number of firms are using it now
column6: and surveys indicate more than 50% of lawyers expect to within the next year
column7: she said. "It's gone much faster than we thought
column8: she said. The problem is
column9: if you don't work with it
column10: you're going to be left behind."

column1: Michel was found guilty in April on all 10 counts he was charged with
column2: including conspiracy and acting as an unregistered agent of a foreign government. He faces up to 20 years in prison on the top counts. He is free ahead of sentencing
column3: which has not yet been set.

column1: At bottom, the AI program failed Kenner, and Kenner failed Michel. The closing argument was deficient, unhelpful, and a missed opportunity that prejudiced the defense, wrote Zeidenberg. His other arguments for a new trial included the jury being prejudiced by being allowed to hear references to the "crime fraud exception" and "co-conspirators."
Michel was accused of funneling money from a now-fugitive Malaysian financer through straw donors to Barack Obama's 2012 reelection campaign
column2: then trying to squelch a Justice Department investigation and influence an extradition case on behalf of China under the Trump administration. His trial included testimony ranging from actor Leonardo DiCaprio to former U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions.

column1: Leonardo DiCapriotakes the stand in Fugees rapper 'Pras' Michel's money-laundering case
Kenner had argued during the trial the Grammy-winning rapper simply wanted to make money and got bad legal advice as he reinvented himself in the world of politics.
It wasn't immediately clear when a judge might rule on the motion for a new trial.
Use of generative AI in the legal profession is in the early stages
column2: but it could see much more widespread adoption as products improve
column3: said John Villasenor
column4: a professor of engineering and public policy at the University of California
column5: Los Angeles. The American Bar Association does not yet have any guidelines on the use of AI in the legal profession
column6: though there is a new task force studying the issue
column7: a spokeswoman said.

column1: Using it for closing arguments is complicated because of the many factors that develop over the course of a trial
column2: he said. Generative AI
column3: meanwhile
column4: also sometimes produces "hallucinations
column5:
statements that initially read as if they are accurate but are not.
A good attorney coming up with closing arguments will be mindful of basic goals of the case but also of the specific ways in which the trial has played out
column6: he said. Even as products improve, attorneys that use AI should make sure they very carefully fact check anything they are going to use."

So if there’s friends of (Meyer's) or boyfriends or things like that where they’re talking about their own private information, that’s the area that obviously we want to protect and ensure is protected as required under California law,'' Dougherty said. “That’s what we’re negotiating on with Stanford right now. We are not seeking to hide anything as it relates to the Meyers or Katie. We have nothing to hide.''
There is no information on the setting of a trial date, according to Jessica Kellogg, communications program manager for the Superior Court of Santa Clara County. 
On Thursday night, when Stanford plays Oregon State, Meyer will be recognized in a variety of ways, according to the school.
Stanford’s players will wear T-shirts that bear the slogan “Katie’s Save,’’ a nod to the initiative of Meyer’s parents to require colleges to give students the option to select a designated advocate. They argue it would have saved their daughter.
As they have all season, Stanford players will wear jerseys with a butterfly patch in honor of Meyer. She loved butterflies.
If you or someone you know may be struggling with suicidal thoughts, you can call the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 800-273-TALK (8255) any time day or night, or chat online.
Crisis Text Line also provides free, 24/7, confidential support via text message to people in crisis when they dial 741741.
A fire broke out on an American Queen Voyages cruise ship Wednesday morning in Portland, Maine, injuring one crew member.
Portland Fire Department crews arrived at 14 Ocean Gateway Pier shortly before 7:30 a.m. local time and received reports of an explosion in the Ocean Navigator vessel’s engine room, possibly related to a generator, according to a news release. The ship was carrying 128 passengers and 82 crew members.
“PFD crews worked quickly to treat and transport one crew member with serious injuries to a local hospital,” the department said. “Additional crews were simultaneously able to stabilize the engine room issue and remained on scene to assist with extensive ventilation efforts and complete overhaul to prevent any further issues.”
Cruise ship medical evacuations:Here's what to know
An American Queen Voyages spokesperson said the ship had a generator fire, but passengers were unharmed “and thanks to the quick action of our crew, everyone has been safely evacuated off of the vessel.” Guests are being housed in a hotel.
The sailing began in Montreal on Oct. 10, according to CruiseMapper.
Nathan Diller is a consumer travel reporter for USA TODAY based in Nashville. You can reach him atndiller@usatoday.com.
Travelers on a recent easyJet flight had to endure every passenger’s worst nightmare when the already delayed flight was canceled after a passenger allegedly defecated on the floor. 
Flight EZY8054 departing from the Spanish island of Tenerife to London Gatwick on Sunday was initially delayed because the plane was overweight and luggage had to be offloaded to the next available flight, Paula Peralta, a spokesperson for the budget airline, told USA TODAY in a statement. 
“The flight was subsequently delayed overnight due to the aircraft requiring additional cleaning,” Peralta added. 
One passenger shared the moment it was announced the flight was canceled until the next day in a video posted on X, formerly Twitter. “(Unintelligible) defecated in the front toilet,” the crew member said in the clip. “So we’re now staying the night here.” 
In the caption of the video, the poster tagged the airline and wrote that the flight was canceled “because someone took a (expletive) on the toilet floor.” 
Learn more: Best travel insurance
More:'It's a party plane': Young man and woman caught having sex on flight to Ibiza
Aaran Gedhu was another passenger on the flight and told CNN that people were already upset and “tense” from the initial delay. The pilot had just announced the flight was cleared to take off in 20 minutes when the defecation incident occurred. 
While the plane was grounded for about an hour, he saw two passengers go to the restroom at the front of the plane. 
Shortly after, a rumor spread in the cabin that someone had defecated on the restroom floor. Gedhu said a bad smell followed. 
“It was just a very uncomfortable experience,” he told CNN, but it was likely an “accident.”
Passengers were given hotel accommodations and another flight was scheduled for the next day.  
“The safety and wellbeing of our customers and crew is easyJet’s highest priority and while this was outside of our control we would like to apologise to customers for the inconvenience caused,” Peralta said. 
Kathleen Wong is a travel reporter for USA TODAY based in Hawaii. You can reach her at kwong@usatoday.com.
U.S. Customs and Border Protection Agriculture Specialists at the Chicago O’Hare International Airport were faced with an unlikely situation after they discovered 15 pounds of raw goat viscera in the baggage of two passengers.
The incident happened on last Tuesday Oct. 10th.
The agency, in a news release, said that two passengers, who were arriving from the Democratic Republic of Congo, were referred to agriculture secondary for inspection.
CBPAS inspected their baggage and found one pound of unknown meat
column2: 2 pounds of garden eggs
column3: and 15 pounds of raw goat viscera including the trachea
column4: heart
column5: lungs
column6: liver
column7: kidneys
column8: and entire digestive system
column9:
said the news release.
A photo provided by the agency shows the internal organs of the goat as an officer holds up the body parts.
An eviscerated goat is certainly outside of the normal items they [CBPAS] stop
column10:
said the new release about the items.
'Fierce argument':Woman throws cash at an airport worker after her mid-flight argument diverted the plane
The news release said that agriculture specialists seized the prohibited items and destroyed them to prevent livestock diseases and plant pests from entering the country.
“There are real dangers these items can have if they are introduced in the U.S. economy,” said CBP Director LaFonda D. Sutton-Burke with the Field Operations-Chicago Field Office.
She urged all passengers, whether entering or returning to the U.S., to be truthful about their baggage and declare all items they are bringing.
If one prohibited item enters the U.S. it could have dangerous ecological or economical results
column11:
emphasized Sutton-Burke.
'Planned to make a necklace':Airport agents seize giraffe poop from woman returning to US
Meanwhile, this is not the first time that a passenger was caught carrying something unusual in their luggage.
Earlier this month on October 6, U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers in Minnesota seized a shipment containing a small box of giraffe poop that was being transported by a passenger returning home from Africa.
Officials with the federal agency working at Minneapolis–Saint Paul International Airport in Minneapolis reported a passenger returning from Kenya arrived at the airport on Sept. 29 and was chosen for inspection by border patrol agriculture specialists.
The passenger declared giraffe feces and stated she had obtained the droppings in Kenya and planned to make a necklace
column12:
according to a press release from the federal regulator.

UPDATE: This story has been updated with news that within hours of publication of USA TODAY's investigation, MSU suspended Coach Mel Tucker without pay.
Two years ago, one of the nation’s star college football coaches and a prominent rape survivor teamed up to fight the culture of sexual violence in sports.
Their partnership should have been a force for good. Instead, it has devolved into scandal, with the activist accusing the coach of the same misconduct that both of them preached against.
The accused is Mel Tucker, the head football coach at Michigan State University and one of the highest paid coaches in all of sports. Accusing him is Brenda Tracy, a rape survivor who has made educating athletes about sexual violence her life’s work.
Over eight months, they developed a professional relationship centered on her advocacy work. Tucker invited Tracy to campus three times – twice to speak to his players and staff and once to be recognized as an honorary captain at the team's spring football game.
But their relationship was upended during a phone call on April 28, 2022, Tracy says in a complaint she filed with the university’s Title IX office in December that remains under investigation.
According to her complaint, Tracy sat frozen for several minutes while Tucker made sexual comments about her and masturbated. His violation, she said, reopened 25-year-old wounds from her rape by four men – two Oregon State University football players, a junior college player and a high school recruit.
“The idea that someone could know me and say they understand my trauma but then re-inflict that trauma on me is so disgusting to me, it’s hard for me to even wrap my mind around it,” she told USA TODAY. “It’s like he sought me out just to betray me.”
In his statements to the Title IX investigator, Tucker acknowledged masturbating on the call but said Tracy grossly mischaracterized the episode. According to him, they had consensual “phone sex.”
“Ms. Tracy’s distortion of our mutually consensual and intimate relationship into allegations of sexual exploitation has really affected me,” Tucker wrote in a March 22 letter to the investigator. “I am not proud of my judgment and I am having difficulty forgiving myself for getting into this situation, but I did not engage in misconduct by any definition.”
Michigan State hired an outside Title IX attorney to investigate the complaint. She finished her investigation in July. A formal hearing to determine whether Tucker violated the school’s policy banning sexual harassment and exploitation is scheduled for Oct. 5 and 6, during the Spartans’ bye week.
The stakes are high for everyone.
Tracy says Tucker is following through on a threat to ruin her career and reputation by painting her as a woman who mixes professional and personal relationships and files false reports. She fears he will undo her legacy.
Tucker, who signed one of the most lucrative contracts in college sports history two years ago, could lose out on the roughly $80 million he is owed if Michigan State fires him for cause, which would be a stunning fall from the elite ranks of college coaches.
Reached by USA TODAY on his cellphone Saturday night, Tucker hung up after a reporter mentioned the case.
Hours after USA TODAY published its investigation, the university suspended Tucker without pay, pending a resolution of the Title IX case.
“This step, suspending Mel Tucker without pay, is … necessary and appropriate for today's circumstances,” Interim President Teresa Woodruff said at a Sunday evening press conference. “These actions are not taken lightly.”
USA TODAY typically does not identify people who allege sexual harassment. Tracy agreed to be identified and shared more than 1,200 pages of case documents.
Title IX, the federal law banning sex discrimination in education, requires schools to investigate allegations of sexual harassment that took place in the context of a school program or activity. Such claims are inherently difficult to adjudicate because of many of the factors at issue in this case: a lack of eyewitnesses and recordings, the passage of time and the thorniness of litigating consent.
Adding to the uncertainty, the institution tasked with sorting out the facts is perhaps best known for missing repeated opportunities to stop one of the most prolific sexual abusers in American history.
For nearly two decades, Michigan State leaders failed to act on complaints against Larry Nassar, the disgraced former U.S.A. Gymnastics and campus physician accused of sexually assaulting more than 300 female athletes under the guise of medical treatments. He has been sentenced to a minimum of 100 years in prison.
Amid its efforts to rebuild trust among students, employees, alumni and the East Lansing community, Michigan State's leaders must now decide whether the face of its prestigious football program is guilty of sexually harassing one of the country’s most influential advocates against gender-based violence.
For some, how the university navigates the crisis will send a clear message about its commitment to progress.
“This goes beyond coach Tucker and Brenda Tracy,” said Jennifer Gomez, a Boston University professor who researches the effects of interpersonal trauma and violence. “What happens here has the potential to be very healing or very harmful for lots and lots and lots of other people.”
Tracy and Tucker met in August 2021 during her first visit to Michigan State, after a mutual acquaintance introduced them.
Standing before a packed auditorium in the Spartans’ football operations building, Tracy told a gut-wrenching story of turning her pain into purpose two decades after filing a police report saying she had been gang-raped as a 24-year-old mother of two.
At the end, she challenged the “good men” in the room to use their privilege and influence to educate themselves and call out bad behavior.
By then she had delivered versions of the speech more than 100 times to at least 40,000 athletes and coaches. Michigan State paid her a $10,000 speaking fee.
Tucker was in his second season as head coach. A former University of Wisconsin-Madison defensive back, he had spent two decades coaching defenses for 10 college and NFL teams before landing the top job at the University of Colorado in late 2018. Michigan State lured him away a year later by doubling his salary.
Mel Tucker's career at Michigan State: A timeline
Tucker and Tracy “hit it off” immediately, they would both later tell the Title IX investigator. They bonded over their love of Jordan sneakers, shelves of which lined Tucker’s office walls.
Tucker had been moved by her speech, and she had been a big hit with players, he told the investigator. They discussed her coming back to campus in the future.
Tracy left East Lansing feeling she had found a champion in Tucker, she told the investigator. He seemed engaged with her cause, leading his players in signing her pledge to, among other things, obtain “ongoing, affirmative consent” before engaging in sexual acts with another person.
Over the next year, their assistants planned two more visits to Michigan State for Tracy, emails, text messages, and itineraries show: the April 2022 spring game where Tracy and her nonprofit, Set The Expectation, would be honored on the jumbotron and a training that July with coaches and players.
During that time, the two also talked on the phone at least 27 times, Tracy’s phone bills show – an average of once every two weeks for a half hour. They often spoke at night to accommodate their work schedules, they said. They chatted about their jobs and eventually more personal matters, such as their families, mental health and daily lives.
They spoke most frequently in fall 2021, while Tucker was leading Michigan State to a 11-2 record – its best season in six years – and negotiating one of the richest coaching contracts of all time.
In November, Michigan State signed him to an unprecedented 10-year, $95 million deal that came fully guaranteed, even if it fired him for poor performance. The only way he could lose out on the money, the contract said, was if he materially breached it, was convicted of a crime or engaged in “conduct which, in the University’s reasonable judgment, would tend to bring public disrespect, contempt or ridicule on the University.”
It was around then that Tucker, who had been married for more than two decades, started becoming interested in Tracy romantically, they both told the investigator.
Whether Tracy reciprocated is where their accounts diverge.
Tucker told the investigator that he and Tracy developed a romantic connection and talked openly about it.
They frequently made flirtatious comments about each other’s looks and bodies, Tucker said. Tracy told him she wanted a “sugar daddy” who would pay her a monthly amount to be his girlfriend, he said, and that she would be “all over” him if he wasn’t married.
Tucker said they had acknowledged their mutual desire for a romance but agreed it would be “too messy” because of his marriage and the physical distance between them.
By contrast, Tracy told the investigator that Tucker’s romantic interest in her was entirely one-sided. She said she came to feel he was less interested in her cause than in her.
Tucker messaged her photos of herself that he had found on her Instagram page, making comments such as, “This is the one,” or complimenting her eyes, Tracy said. Tucker also sent her two gifts – a pair of Jordans and $200 in cash through Venmo – and donated $2,500 to her nonprofit.
Once, Tucker called Tracy via FaceTime. He was in bed, shirtless. He talked about his unhappy marriage, describing himself as “more or less single.” Then, during a Nov. 9, 2021, call, she said he asked her, “If I wasn’t a football coach and if I wasn’t married, would you date me?”
Tracy said she responded that she would not because they worked together – one of several times she recalled trying to set boundaries. She said she made clear to Tucker on a Dec. 1 call that they would only be friends, and he seemed to agree.
Then, after the spring game, Tucker called her four times, phone records show. Tracy said he repeatedly asked her to meet him alone, without her assistant, and even suggested slipping into her hotel through a back door so no one would see him. She said no.
Twelve days later came the call.
Tracy was in her home office in Oregon. Tucker, who was in a hotel in Florida, called her at 12:39 a.m. EST, phone records show. The call lasted 36 minutes.
According to Tucker, he became aroused when Tracy made a comment about needing to hit the gym more to look better without clothes on. They then discussed how having phone sex could complicate their relationship, he said, but Tracy suggested once would be harmless and he agreed.
“Unequivocally, there’s no doubt about it,” Tucker told the investigator, case documents show. “She was the one who said we’ll do it.”
Tracy denies all of that. The call started off normal, she said. But when she sent Tucker a photo of them together from the spring game, she said he responded by commenting on her buttocks and calling himself an “ass man.”
She remembered Tucker’s voice getting deeper and weirder as he continued talking about her buttocks. She asked him what he was doing, and he said he had a “hard dick” and was touching himself.
“You’re touching yourself?” Tracy asked, according to the investigation report. Tucker responded, “Yes.”

column1: Tucker
column2: however

column3: Michigan-based Title IX attorney

column1: A former Indiana sex crimes prosecutor who now heads a private practice

column1: Tracy’s other three witnesses – her assistant

Although Veidlinger had interviewed all six of Tracy’s witnesses before the end of January

Tucker sat down for his interview on March 22.
He said he wanted to be transparent and set the record straight. But Veidlinger would note some key inconsistencies.
For instance

column4: Tucker said

Along the way

On a sunny Thursday morning
column2: Michigan State University football coach Mel Tucker strolled through tomato fields at a farm in Immokalee
column3: Florida
column4: toured its processing plants and loaded baskets of bright green fruit into a truck.

column4: tour
column5: disclosed in records obtained by USA TODAY this week

column4: a prominent rape survivor and activist he had hired to speak to his team about sexual violence.

column1: It’s just one example of Tucker failing to keep his story straight at the most consequential moment of his career.
With his job

column3: Tucker repeatedly made false statements to the investigator and misled her about basic facts

column5: a USA TODAY review of more than 1
column6: 200 pages of case documents found.

column1: Per his contract

column3: a formal hearing to determine whether Tucker violated school policies against sexual harassment and exploitation is expected to proceed on Oct. 5 and 6.

column1: Since his suspension

column4: the central details of his story changed entirely.

column1: Tucker
column2: who previously hung up on a reporter who called him on his cellphone asking about the case
column3: did not respond to a message seeking comment for this story. His attorney
column4: Jennifer Belveal

column1: In the absence of eyewitnesses or recordings
column2: sexual harassment cases usually boil down to whose account is more credible
column3: said Elizabeth Abdnour
column4: a Lansing-based attorney and former Michigan State Title IX investigator who has taken part in dozens of campus cases.

column1: “It’s very
column2: very unusual that you would have some outside piece of evidence that would give you a clear decision
column3: ” Abdnour said. “Very often you’re weighing credibility based on little bits and pieces of information.”

column1: In multiple cases she has worked
column2: Abdnour said the respondents lost because they were found to have a greater propensity for lying than the complainants. The hearing officer must determine how much weight to give Tucker’s false and conflicting statements
column3: Abdnour said
column4: and they could sway the case in Tracy’s favor.

column1: “I believe a fact finder could assess these pieces of evidence about credibility and make a determination that Brenda is more credible than Mel
column2: ” she said. “In my experience
column3: a clear sign of a lack of credibility is generally taken very seriously.”

column1: By the time Tucker met with Veidlinger for his interview

column1: The school had informed him of Tracy’s complaint on Dec. 22
column2: the day after she filed it. Veidlinger had interviewed Tracy and all six of her witnesses by the end of January. Tucker was the only holdout.

column1: Rather than tell his side of the story right away

Meanwhile
column2: their assistants were planning Tracy’s third visit to campus – an in-person training with coaches and players scheduled for July 25.

column2: the investigation report shows. When Tracy spoke to him by phone on Aug. 2 seeking to find out why

Reached by USA TODAY
